item.title: Experimenting with flies for cold water Tenkara
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded: Since the Tenkara fishing season kicked off just over a month ago I have found that the trout pay no mind to a tasty looking traditional kebari. So I switched to heavier flies to get at the trout hangin' out on the bottom of the river. Surprisingly I had the greatest luck with a lightning bug that I found on the bank of the Gunpowder in Maryland last season. Then I caught a nice tree branch with it and rather than consign myself to looking at fish instead of catching them I started tying my own. Lo' and behold they worked, quite well in fact and much to the shock and disbelief of many Japanese anglers. One very friendly anglerÂ said that the Japanese fly fish with very tiny flies, around size 26, and she couldn't believe I was catching fish with a size 12 hook! item.title: Oshino - A Photo Exploration
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded: Last week I headed back to Oshino Creek. I didn't have a chance toÂ fish the lower sections the firstÂ time I went. The lower sections features more swift water than the upper section and I was eager to check it out. For the most part Oshino is a slow and deep river but the sections of "white-water" do offer some great fishing.   [gallery link="none" columns="1" size="large" ids="897"] When we arrived the sun was shining and the most impressive lenticular cloud I had ever seen was perched over the top of Mount Fuji. The cloud was flowing down the side of the mountain in cascading wisps. It was an absolutely beautiful morning! As the day progressed ominous clouds began to blow in. [gallery link="none" columns="1" size="large" ids="899"] There were more anglers on the river than last time but they tended to congregate around the deeper pools. It was still possible to find solitude surrounded by budding trees and blooming flowers. With the warmer weather comes more wildlife encounters. I almost step on the first snake I've seen in Japan. Glad he isn't poisonous!   It was a productive day with many fish brought to hand including a very nice Brook Trout. I didn't catch anyÂ Iwana, Amago, or Yamame though... [gallery link="none" columns="2" size="large" ids="898,900"] At the end of the day we headed over to Rivers Edge Fishing Store. They have a wide selection of fly fishing gear including a large selection of fly tying materials. The owner was very friendly offering all sorts of information and they also have a cafÃ© with many tables and outdoor seating. They also sell fishing licenses and full season tickets in case you'd rather go here instead of Lawsons. They open at 8am M-S.   Subscribe to Fallfish Tenkara by Email

item.title: Maxpedition Noatak Gearslinger
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
When I first started Tenkara I used a Coleman cooler sleeveÂ to carry my tenkara rod and gear with me on the river. It worked ok but more importantly itÂ was simple, cheap, and lightweight. However, when I put a bottle of water inside the 1" webbing sling would dig into my shoulder, and after a few hours I had some serious neck pain issues. I had received the Maxpedition Noatak Gearslinger as a birthday present from a good friend a year or two back. I mainly used it for school and for short rides on my bike. It was sitting in my gear closet, with my other twenty or so packs, and so I decided to give it a shot. After my first Tenkara outing with the Noatak Gearslinger I knew I had discovered my perfect fishing pack. What I Love About It For starters it sits squarely and comfortably on my back. It's not too big and bulky and it doesn't get in the way. When I go Tenkara fly-fishing I like to stay on the river for hours, if not the entire day. Consequently I carry everything I'll need for a full day on the river. With Tenkara you don't need that much - so I don't need a big pack. I just require enough room for my rod (of course), lunch, a water bottle, some extra tippet, fluorocarbon line, my Tacky Fly Box, my keys, wallet, iPhone, bug spray, and my Gerber Dime multi-tool. The Gunslinger is just the right size to carry these items. The Gearslingers features a concealed carry pocket that is right up against the back. It is the perfect pouch to slide a Tenkara rod or three into. If I need my hands free to negotiate a tricky ascent or descent I can easily slide my collapsed Tenkara rod into this pocket. When I'm ready to retrieve it, I effortlessly reach back and grab it (just like pulling an arrow from a quiver). The Gunslinger is a sling bag, meaning it only has one strap. This is probably the best feature, imo, because it allows one to quickly and easily flip the bag from behind you to right in front of you. This not only gives you very easy access to anything inside your bag but can also double as a "table" when tying a new fly on or cutting a new length of line. [gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="1066,1017,1014"] What I Do Not Like Despite the well padded sling, after a long day on the river the pack can make my shoulder a little sore. It would be nice if there was a way to switch the pack to the other shoulder (maybe a detachable sling), to distribute the load. To be fair this problem only surfacesÂ when I am carrying a lot of food/water. With a lighter load there is no discomfort, even on really long days on the river. It isn't waterproof.

item.title: Lifestraw Personal Water Filtration
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
For Christmas I got a Lifestraw Go, which is a pretty coolÂ personal water filtration system. I had been eyeing getting one for some time but had always found other things to spend my money on such as gas for fishing trips or a new mountain bike... The Lifestraw Go is a canteen with a filter element that is built into the cap. The filter is replaceable so the unit should last for a very long time. The thing I like most about the Lifestraw Go is that it is light, simple, and bomb proof. (Authors Note: Quick subject change but I feel it is relevant) - I had used a Sawyer Squeeze Water Filtration system for years. While I enjoyed its simplicity and the fact that it is the lightest water purification solution on the market (besides tablets/UV) it did have some drawbacks. The biggest problem was that the bags broke down quickly, after a season the bags started sprouting holes. Also the filter unit would not screw on properly after about 6-8 months of use and would leak un-purified water, which if you weren't careful would run down the bag and into the canteen.Â  The Lifestraw doesn't have the problems that the Sawyer system had. Of course the Lifestraw cannot purify water for say putting into a pot to heat up and put in your food... So it does have someÂ limitations. The water can only be drawn through the filter via suction from your mouth. It is not gravity or pressure fed. Of course there are those out there who would be freaked out by the plastic leaching EA (estrogen activity) into the water despite the fact that the Lifestraw Go is BPA free (here is myÂ sourceÂ in case you hadn't heard). To reduce the leaching of EA into my water IÂ keep the canteen empty until I need water. Once I've drank my fill I just dump any remaining water out of the canteen. Carrying around an empty canteen that I only need to fill when I'm thirsty has allowed me to significantly lighten theÂ load. I don't need to carry a heavy canteen filled with water while I'm fishing in water! Sometimes though I do have to carry a full canteen when I'm fishing as some streams you couldn't pay me enough to drink out of. For example,Â rivers that flow through agricultural areas where pesticide use and or farm animals impact water quality. But for mountain streams the Lifestraw Go is a perfect solution. I should note that some folks have reported being unable to draw water through the Lifestraw filter after a few sips. While I have never had this problem with my Lifestraw apparently the solution is to soak the filter for several minutes. Lifestraw does not publicize this solution for whatever reason but if you're having this problem in the backcountry it is good to know there is a solution... item.title: Tenkara in Los Angeles
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded: IÂ have beenÂ vacationing in Los Angeles this past week. Next week is a backpacking trip in the High Sierra and the following week I'll be in Texas. After that I will be headed back to Japan.Â I was able to sneak away from from vacation obligationsÂ for a trip up the West Fork of the San Gabriel River (WFSGR) today. The San Gabriel river has a lot of history in Southern California and is one of the only streams that supports trout in the newly created San Gabriel National Monument. The riversÂ close proximity to Los Angeles ensures that the fishing pressure is high - combined with my late start, the high temps,Â and zero cloud coverÂ I knew the conditions were going to be challenging. I did not really care if I didn't catch any fish, I just needed to get out of the chaos of "civilization" for awhile. I had never been to the West Fork of the San Gabriel River before. But a few weeks ago I read a greatÂ post from LA River Fly FishingÂ and I decided that when I got back to the States I'd head over to the West Fork and check it out. [gallery link="none" columns="2" size="medium" ids="1242,1243"] The parking lot closest to the gate was full (only 6 spots) but the one just up the road was empty! As I hiked up the access road, that takes one to Cogswell Dam and then on to Mt. Wilson, I passed many hikers, bikers, several families swimming in the river, and only one fishermen heading out. He hadn't had any luck and was going up to Crystal Lake to catch some fish with his daughter. I pressed on. I caught glimpses of the WFSGR through the trees, sometimes the river was right up against the road other times it was hundreds of feet away. After hiking about a mile I spotted a nice looking section and made my way down to the river, being careful not to disturb any rattlesnakes. [gallery link="none" columns="2" size="medium" ids="1244,1245"] Despite the drought conditions the river was flowing nicely and I came across many deep pools. In a few spots where I misjudged the depth I plunged in up to my chest. The cool water felt great in the heat. The flowers were in full bloom and there were bugs of all shapes and sizes flying about. I started out with a #18 terrestrialÂ - then moved on to a #18 olive prince nymph. The fish were playing with the nymph but I wasn't getting any realÂ interest. I continued up stream. The wind was wreaking havoc with my line, the 7x tippet was getting snarled up constantly so finally I gave up and switched to 5x. I thought that this would nix any hopeÂ of catching fish because the water wasÂ clear but this was not to be the case. [gallery link="none" columns="2" size="medium" ids="1246,1247"] I came across a beautiful pool, with about a dozen fishÂ splashing and darting about. A few swam up to within a few feet of me, sniffing at my legs before darting away. I tied on a #12 kebari from TenkaraUSAÂ and began making my way up the pool casting to the spots where I thought the fish were. Within a minute or two I had hooked into a beautiful 4" rainbow. The fish didn't seem fazed though and the turtles were perched on a rock gawking at the show so I pressed on. A few minutes later I hookedÂ a beautiful 7" Rainbow. He was a spirited little fellow jumping straight out of the water about 2-3' before darting all over the pool. He tired quickly though and obliged me a few photos before being quickly returned to the water. [gallery link="none" columns="2" size="medium" ids="1248,1249"] I had made plans to have dinner with some friends and so I began making my way back to the car. The winds had picked up and the temperature was dropping. I could smell BBQ as I drew closer to the parking lot, which reminded me that I had been having so much fun I had forgotten to eat lunch! I had lived in Los Angeles before moving to Maryland and Japan, but had been more interested in the mountain tops then the valleys. The mountains of Los Angeles are chock full of little gems - the West Fork of the San Gabriel River is certainly one of those gems. [gallery link="none" columns="2" size="medium" ids="1251,1252"] Subscribe to Fallfish Tenkara by Email

item.title: Sierra Nevada Mountains
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded: The Sierra Nevada Mountains located in California has become a mecca for me. Every year since I was very young I have travelled to this majestic mountain range and explored her peaks, valleys, deserts, and rivers. This year the agenda was to backpack up toÂ Baxter Pass and depending on the weather possibly head into the Rae Lakes Basin. Due to ominous looking weather and a wicked bout of altitude sickness the plan to go to Rae Lakes was dropped and instead we opted to fish the Upper Owens River and explore the Ancient Bristlecone Pine Forest. [gallery link="none" size="medium" columns="2" ids="1268,1269"] [gallery link="none" columns="1" size="large" ids="1270"] The trail up to Baxter Pass is one of the most rugged and secluded of the east side of the Sierra Nevada Mountains. WithÂ over 6,000 feet of elevation gain in roughly 8 miles the trail is unrelentingly steep. [gallery link="none" columns="1" size="full" ids="1271"] After descending from Baxter Pass in an intermittent snow and hail storm we arrived at the trail-head starved and in need of a bath. A nice deep pool in Oak Creek and we were smelling better for a few beers and a steak at TotemÂ CafÃ©. We camped in the BLM land of the Alabama Hills and early the next morning we were greeted with a spectacular sunrise! [gallery link="none" columns="1" size="large" ids="1272"] The best breakfast on the 395 corridorÂ is at the smallÂ Alabama Hills CafÃ©. There is almost always a wait for a table but it's totally worth it. I had the Clint Eastwood Skillet and washed it down with several cups of black coffee. Then we hit the road and headed north - our destination was the Upper Owens River. [gallery link="none" columns="2" size="medium" ids="1273,1274"] [gallery link="none" columns="1" size="large" ids="1276"] Trout Unlimited's Guide to America's 100 Best Trout Streams says that the Upper Owens River is "California's quintessential spring creek and perhaps it's richest trout fishery. An estimated 7,000 to 11,000 browns and rainbows per mile lurk beneath undercut banks and under aquatic grasses." [gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="1277,1279,1278"] The river flows through a lush meadow surrounded by sage brush and the 14,000 foot peaks of the Sierra Nevada Mountains and the White Mountains as a backdrop. It is a river perfectly suited for Tenkara. The river isn't veryÂ wide, so my 11'6" Tenkara rod was able toÂ effectively fish the opposite bank if need be. Trout Unlimited's Guide to America's 100 Best Trout Streams states that "Fishing is difficult. Vibrations from walking its grassy banks spook trout. Gusts from incessant winds grab your casts. Myriad microcurrents like the wrinkles in old glass impart drag to your fly that you cannot begin to see."Â  While we were there, several storms blew across the valley. We were caught in several rain storms and were treated to an impressive lightening display over the distant mountains. The storms created a lot of wind which made casting difficult to impossible. However, we still brought eight trout to hand, had about half a dozen on the line that got off, and numerous bites. The fishÂ were rising and darting about all day. On several occasionsÂ we spotted some very large troutÂ in the 18-20" category! I even spotted a massive crayfish but she darted under an undercut before I could snap her photo... [gallery link="none" size="medium" columns="2" ids="1281,1297"] After 6+ hours on the river we headed back into town for gas and food before driving up to the Ancient Bristlecone Pine Forest deep in the heart of the White Mountains. [gallery link="none" columns="1" size="large" ids="1283"] We camped at Grandview Campground which is located at 8,900'. It is one of the best campgrounds in the US to view meteor showers due to its distance from light pollution and the high altitude which also affordsÂ one a clear view of the night sky. [gallery link="none" columns="2" size="medium" ids="1284,1285"] Early the next day we packed up camp and made the long drive back to Los Angeles. I had a plane to catch, laundry to do, and I was hoping to squeeze in a short trip on the Los Angeles River too! Subscribe to Fallfish Tenkara by Email

item.title: Los Angeles River
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
Ever since I discovered Tenkara the Los Angeles River has been high on my list of rivers to fish. It may seem a little odd to want to fish one of theÂ most polluted rivers in the US so badly - a river of whichÂ nearly 100% of its natural habitat has been decimated. ButÂ the Los Angeles River is making a comeback and I dig comeback stories. In 50 years when the steelhead finally return I want to say I fished the river when the 180 began (b.t.w.Â this book is a great read and the $ goes to a great cause). I want to be a part of that story of restoration. Anglers now flock to the river to try their luck at catching base, tilapia, bluegill, catfish, and above all carp (whichÂ is populating more and moreÂ hipster Instagram feeds). Not to mention I had lived very close to it for years and never went to check it out so I felt I owed it to myself to go see what all the fuss was about.

[gallery link="none" columns="2" size="medium" ids="1304,1303"]

So within a few hours of returning from an awesome trip to the High Sierra I hooked up with a new Tenkara buddy and we headed down to the Los Angeles River. We parked at Marsh Street Nature Park,Â which is very close to the intersection of the 2 Freeway and Interstate 5. Power lines crisscrossed the clear blue sky and the sounds of air brakes and trains were only drowned out when you were standing in the river. It was a stark contrast to the tranquility of the Upper Owens River that I had just fished the day before. Still I was happy.

[gallery link="none" columns="2" size="medium" ids="1301,1302"]

I was very surprised to see so much water in the river. Because of the current drought California is experiencing I was expecting it to be a trickle but there is enough water in the river for kayaks and I spotted a large group while fishing a shallow pool.Â After fishing several promising looking spots, and only catching one 3â baby small mouth bass (or maybe it was a mosquito fish?), we headed to the Spokes CafÃ© for some refreshments. We had only explored a very small section of the river closest to the park but I had been pleasantly surprised by what I had found in the river channel. There was an abundance of life, the water was deep and wide in many places, there wasn't too much trash, and I felt strangely refreshed but above all I was excited to see what the future holds for the Los Angeles River.

To get involved or to just get more information be sure to check out LA River Fly FishingÂ

item.title: Joshua Creek - Boerne, Texas
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded: Last month epic amounts of rainfall hammered the karst hill country of Texas. After the flooding subsided springs throughout the area erupted with new life and the rivers ran at full capacity. My parents own a small plot of land on the outskirtsÂ of Boerne Texas and Joshua Creek is just 1.5 miles from their front door. Last fall when I visited JoshuaÂ Creek was nothing more than a string of stagnant pools filled with algae. However, this time around Joshua Creek was full of life, filled to capacity, and incredibly clear. [gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="1325,1326,1327"] We traveled to the river in my Dad's 1974 Jeep everyday and I would bring all of my Tenkara rods with me. I taught close to a dozen Tenkara lessons to my brothers, sisters, and my brothers wives. It was a Tenkara family reunion! In the course of week we caught close to a hundred Bluegill, Longear Sunfish, Redbreast Sunfish, Small Mouth Bass, and maybe even a few Pumpkinseed!Â The creekÂ was as warm as a bathtub, wet wading was the name of the game - especially in the heat of the afternoon. [gallery link="none" columns="2" size="medium" ids="1328,1329"] Not to far from Joshua Creek is the famous Guadalupe River! Last fall I had fished the upper Guadalupe River but this trip the riverÂ was still in flood stage flowing deep, fast and not very clear - so we opted to just fish Joshua Creek instead. Trout Unlimited lists the lower Guadalupe River (below Canyon Lake which is only 40 miles from Boerne Texas) as one of the top 100 Trout Streams in the USA! The upperÂ Guadalupe River, while not suitable for trout, is worth a visit if you're in the area. It stays fishable late into the season and I have yet to come across any other anglers on either the Guadalupe River or Joshua Creek during my multiple visits. [gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="1331,1332,1333"] Of course no visit to Boerne Texas would be complete without dining at Marys Tacos and Mague's CafÃ© - quite possibly the best mexican food on the planet :) Subscribe to Fallfish Tenkara by Email

item.title: SPOT Satellite Messenger
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
For several years I have carried a SPOT Satellite GPS Messenger (Gen II)Â with me into the backcountry. It offers peace of mind, not only for myself, but for my family. I travel solo on most of my adventures and appreciate the ability to share my location and a quick message that all is ok when I am out of cell phone reception. (See Author's Note at the bottom of the page for update).Â I have the older second generation unit, which works fine for me. I donât need the continuous tracking feature that the Gen III model offers. The Gen III model claims twice the battery life overÂ the older Gen II model. However, I have used the same batteries for over a year now in my Gen II model so I feel no immediate need to upgrade to the Gen III model.Â 

SPOT claims a 96% probability of message delivery over most of the globe. I have found this to be true but only when using the unit in areas with no overhead foliage or dense cloud cover. If there are any trees blocking the sky, the message has about a 50/50 chance of being delivered. It requires a $149 subscription once the unit has been purchased which is billed annually.

[gallery link="file" size="full" ids="1769,1770,1771"]

The unit, which is waterproof to one meter, has six buttons:

  • Power On/Off
  • A check in button that you can customize with a message.Â 
  • You can also send a one pre-programed message - for example âIâm running late but everything is fine.â
  • You can mark your location on a Google Map that you can share with only your loved ones or publicly.
  • A help button which you can use to summon help from friends or family but not the authorities.
  • Lastly there is an SOS button which alerts the GEOS International Emergency Response Coordination Center and provides your GPS coordinates and information to local response teams.

[pullquote align=center]

... The average response time from the receipt of your 911/SOS message until referring an emergency responder is only 11 minutes, wherever you are in the world.

[/pullquote]

The unit is small (9.4cm X 6.6cm X 2.5cm), and light (just under 150 grams), and powered by three (3) AAA lithium batteries, it operates in temperatures from -30Ë Celsius to 60Ë Celsius, and from -100 meters to 6,500 meters. I have dropped it, submerged it, and carried it over hundreds of trail miles and cross country all over the US and Japan. I have found that it works best when stationary, do not try sending a message while moving. Also it is best to send several messages a day in case one doesn't make it through. SPOT Satellite Messengers have helped rescueÂ 3,500 people all over the world, I hope to never need that service but the ability to check in with my loved ones is more than worth the yearly subscription fee to me.

Subscribe to Fallfish Tenkara by Email

Author's Note:

After two years of somewhat reliable service (I'd say about 80% of my messages were received) my Spot Messenger stopped sending any messages. After numerous attempts at sending messages on various trips I contacted Spot for a refund. After sending three emails I received a response and without asking any questions they processed a refund within a week. I will now be looking into alternate methods to communicate while I am in the backcountry.

Not sure how they pulled that one off, nevertheless it has some cool content. There are also half gigabyte videos that can be freely downloaded from the site along with high resolution photos of Sansai too! Hiking Blogs Tozan Tales Ridgeline Images
Authors Observation: I debated adding this observation but I feel that I must, and since it is my blog here it is: When I visited California in June I had the distinct pleasure of fishing the Upper Ownens River. Trout Unlimited's Guide toÂ America's 100 Best Trout Streams had this to say about the river "...the Owens is California's quintessential spring and perhaps its richest trout fishery. An estimated 7,000 to 11,000 browns and rainbows per mile lurk beneath undercut banks and under aquatic grasses." Seven to eleven thousand!? That is unbelievable. When I tell aÂ Japanese personÂ what my job is (a Tenkara guide) often times they proudly pull out their phone and show me pictures of them holding 10, 20, 30, 40 fish that they pulled from a river. I've seen ocean fishermen carryingÂ buckets filled with tiny fish taking them back home to eat. The catch and release culture that permeates the American fishing scene hardlyÂ existsÂ in Japan. In the week leading up toÂ September 30 (that included Silver Week) I would not be surprised to learn that tens of millions of fresh water fish died. It's a staggering number. This kind of fishing ethic is rooted in the same way of thinkingÂ that nearly wiped out the American buffalo. There are warning signs everywhere that there is a big problem in Japan but no one here seems to care. There are many things I love about Japan butÂ it frustratesÂ me to no end to see how destructive they are with their environment. Their entire country is smaller than California. They don't have a lot of room for error. I can guarantee you with 100%Â certaintyÂ that there is not a single river in the entire country of Japan that has seven to eleven thousand fish per mile. Not a single one. Are there still great rivers for fishing in Japan? Absolutely! It's just nowhere as good as it could be. When I first started Fallfish Tenkara I envisioned a format similar to www.switchfisher.comÂ with driving directions, parking info, maps, and GPS coordinates. I quickly realized that that would be a horrible idea. In America you keep a creek a secret because you don't want to see anyone. In Japan you keep a river a secret because if you don't then there won't be any fish left in it next week.Â  So what is the purpose of this rant, other than to let off some steam? Well I'm glad you asked! You may not be a conservation minded person - it's quite easy to not care about conservation in America where there is so much natural untouched beauty. You can just think that someone else will take care of it, someone else will protect it. Well I've seen what happens first hand when no one does anything and the destruction of a natural habitat runs rampant and unchecked. It's ugly and Japan may never fully recover from those mistakes. So today I joined Trout Unlimited. I may not be currently living or guiding in the United States but IÂ can do something about conservation and preservation in the country listed on my passport. It is time to put my money where my mouth is plusÂ I've alway been impressed with their conservation and preservation efforts so I know I will be supporting aÂ legitimate organization.Â  In the meantime I'll keep sharing about the beauty I see everyday in Japan, and who knows maybe one day it will inspire a conservation revolution in Japan.Â 
There are two things that I have been pondering as of late, well that's not entirely true - it is a lot more than two but only two are relevant so I am only going to write about them for now. First, is catch and release ethics. I read this really great post from Gink and Gasoline. It is all about how to not harm the fish that you are photographing and it got me thinking. Since I live close to Tokyo, I fish close to Tokyo and on a lot of the rivers the fishing pressure is very high. Combined with the prevalent dams, weirs, and man-made banks and channels it is very difficult if not impossible for any species of fish to inhabit theÂ river from season to season. Then along come all the anglers (keiryu, bait, lure, tenkara, fly, etc...), most of whoÂ keep everything they catch (of course there are the small few who release what they catch). But it would appear that those few practicing catch and release don't know what they are doing. By a long shot I have seen more floaters, a.k.a. dead fish, floating down the river (or at the bottom of pools) than fish that I have caught, and I have caught a fair number of fish in the time that I've been here. I read this interesting article, it's a little outdated, but as far as I can tell it is still accurate. Then there is this more recent article. It is a little more recent but still it's from last year. However, what it shows is that Japan is in trouble. The culture is so enthralled with fish, they are loving it to death. So many of the fishing operations also advertising deals on charcoal and other cooking apparatus. You can cook your days catch right there next to your numbered pool that you paid Â¥4000 to fish out of for the day. I've seen anglers rip the hook out their 2" catch and toss itÂ over their shoulder into the sand and continue fishing. The lack of respect is sickening and makes me a little mad. I could expect this behavior at fish farms but when you see it out in nature you do a double take. It reminds me of beaver hunters in North America in the 18th and 19th century, or the buffalo hunters in the 19th century - just killing for the sake of it. No thought given to what the greater effect is. Now I'm a gaijin, and believe me every single day I am aware of this fact. It's not really my problem. In a few years I'll leave this island and go back to my home country. Honestly, in America we aren't doing much better and in some ways we are probably doing worse. In the grand scheme of things does it really matter that a natural habitat is being destroyed slowly but surely? It probably won't happen in my lifetime so what do I care? And therein lies the realÂ problem...
The second thing that I've been pondering is anglers apprehension for talking about the name of a stream or where it is located. Now some streams cannot handle more than a dozen anglers a season and if you start spewing information on the best trail head access or GPS coordinates then the damage done in one season may never be reversed. I totally get that but when you are posting photos of a stream with a highway bridge in the shot do you really need to be secretive about it? I used to be a surfer. I say "used to" because I have never met a more snobby group of assholes in my life. After my firstÂ death threat and after my first threat of having my tires slashed for sitting on my board in the water (I wasn't even near the wave yet) - I sold my board and I've never looked back. This world is far to big to waste my time with such a pathetic group of people. Now I know that that is exactly why those individuals said those things to me. The pressure on that particular "break"Â was extreme and there is no room for "newbies". One person who quits is one less person preventing themÂ from catching that sick whitewater in the polluted waters of Huntington Beach. I would ask a surfer where the parking was for Truffles and they'd clam up. Not a peep. Not even a close landmark. Compared to rock climbers who will tell you EVERYTHING you need to know and probably a bunch of stuff you didn't need to know "The first ascent was done by so and so. He climbed it naked with the rope tied to his junk." (true story by the way) Now I'm going to stop my story here for a second and go on a tirade about the Japanese obsession with weirs. They seem to love building these monstrosities as much as they love sake, eating fish, and smoking! I can understand their use in populated areas but do you really need to build them in the middle of nowhere? There is no threat to any man-made structure from flooding. If you can show me one creek in Japan that doesn't have a weir built on it I'll be very surprised and I'll buy you a six pack. These pointless man-made obstructions prevent fish from migrating upstream to spawning grounds and creates isolated pockets of fish. This not only weakens the gene-pool but makes it very easily for one inconsiderate angler to decimate the fish population. Ok, now that I've gotten that off my chest...

item.title: Patagonia's Black Hole Duffel Bags
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
To say that I love my Patagonia Black Hole Duffel bags is an understatement! I have hammered the living daylights out of mine for years and they still look brand new!They are absolutely bomb proof! I own two 120 Liters Black Hole Duffel Bags,Â as well as a 45 Liters Duffel,Â and the 45 Liters Wheeled Duffel.Â I bring at least one of them on nearly all of my trips. Next on my list of gear acquisitions is the Black Hole Messenger 25L (that matches my 45L Wheeled Duffel of course) and maybe a Black Hole Pack. In my opinion they are the best gear duffel bagsÂ on the market! What I Love
  • A standard length Tenkara rod tube will fit in both the standard and wheeled 45L bags, but just barely (if the tube was 1/2â longer it wouldnât fit). For the wheeled bag I had to put the Tenkara rod on the bottom and it didnât fit end to end but rather corner to corner.
  • The wheeled 45L bag works great as a carry on, which is what I bought it for. Despite my reservations at its size when fully stuffed it always fit in the overhead bins. On my recent trip to the US I took the 45L wheeled duffel andÂ the airline staff never once forced me to check it at the gate due to its size. I was able to fit enough clothing and gear in the 45L Wheeled Black Hole Duffel for a wedding, Tenkara fly fishing, day to dayÂ clothing, and toiletries for seven days!
  • The standard 45L Black Hole Duffel is perfect for holding a few changes of clothes and is my go to everyday carry for all of my skiing, hiking, Tenkara, ice climbing, rock climbing guided trips.
  • The 120L bags are humongous and can swallow nearly anything that I need to carry. During my cross country move from California to Maryland I lived out of one 120L duffel for over 9 weeks! My wife loved mine so much I had to buy her her own for when we moved to Japan (hers is the blue one).
  • I really dig Patagoniaâs dedication to the environment, fair trade practices, Worn Wear, and earth first approach to sourcing textiles. It is a breath of fresh air in our consumer driven society. They offer a lot of other great bags, not just in the Black Hole categoryÂ that you should check out.
  • Patagonia products are tough. Iâve blown out other brands clothing in under one season. My Patagonia Zip-Off PantsÂ have survived 5 seasons of brutal use and are going on their 6th. Seriously that is AMAZING! And donât even get me started on my Patagonia Nano Air Hoody JacketÂ (which I would marry if I couldâ¦ Okay thatâs a little excessive but seriously it is the BEST jacket ever made). I fully expect the Black Hole duffel bagsÂ that I own to last a lifetime.
What I Donât Like
  • Unfortunately, my TenkaraUSA Ito rod does not fit in the 45L bags. My other Tenkara rods (in their protective tubes) barely fit. Besides the Tenkara Rod Co. Mini rods (of which I donât own any) there really isnât any carry on friendly Tenkara rods. I think that should change - not really Patagoniaâs fault, just an observationâ¦
  • The only time Iâve run out of room with the 120L bags is when Iâm packing ski touring equipment, including my ski boots, for an overnight ski tour trip (sleeping bag, tent, rope, etcâ¦). It would be nice if Patagonia offered a 160L option (that big though would probably only be doable as a wheeled option).
  • While Iâm dreaming of other bags they could offer a Ski Boot Black Hole Bag (and maybe even a Ski-Board/Boot combo wheeled bag) would be awesome!

item.title: 45Air Review
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
A Great Wordpress Managed Hosting Solution

When I first launched Fallfish Tenkara in JanuaryÂ of 2015 it was on aÂ virtual private server (VPS) that I built through Amazon Web Services (AWS). However, my lack of expertise at server maintenance and IT became rapidly apparent. Within a few weeks my server crashed and could not be restored. So I built another, and another, and another. Finally I opted for a DigitalOcean droplet (which was much more stable than my AWS VPS) to self-host Fallfish Tenkara on. Due to too much content and a lot of traffic though I soon outgrew my first DigitalOcean droplet and had to upgrade to a larger and more expensive droplet. While self-hosting offered a lot of flexibility I wasÂ solely responsible for support. I found myself putting out one fire after another. PHP wasn't playing nice with a server update. Editing sudo privileges. XML-RPC vulnerabilities. Firewalls. SSH keys. Overloaded CPU's. Debugging. Error messages. The list was never ending. While it was a learning experience that I enjoyed (in a masochistic sort of way) it was also very frustrating and tiring.Â If I was making any money at all this it might have been worth it, but the site was costing me money and causing me a lot of stress. SoÂ I decided I needed to make a change and began looking intoÂ managed hosting options. I had many reasons to go with a managed hosting option instead ofÂ a cheaper shared hosting plan as managed hostingÂ offers:
  • Better Security
  • Faster Speed
  • Managed WordPress updates
  • Daily backups
  • Near 100% website uptime
While doing my research I looked into a lot of managed hosting companies. But there was one based in Ohio that looked especially promising - 45Air I ended up choosing them and here's why...
There were severalÂ things that caught my eye about 45Air. First off their pricing is very competitive. While there were other slightly cheaper options out there the competition tended to offer smaller and less powerful servers. As far as bang for your buck 45Air was hard to beat. The other thing isÂ their collaboration with CloudFlare. CloudFlare is a really cool service that I had employed on my site very early on. With site traffic coming to Fallfish Tenkara from all around the world I needed a robust Content Delivery Network (CDN) which CloudFlare offers. While I was able to self-host with CloudFlare's free plan I had long drooled over the features that paid plans had access to. Railgun was one of those services that I thought was pretty cool but at $200 a month there was no way I was going to pay forÂ it... However,Â 45Air offers it to all of their customers. Railgun helpsÂ my content load just as fast in the USA as it does in Japan, Turkey, Thailand, and Great Britain. 45Air also offers a proprietary server side caching service called Blackbird Cache that is powered byÂ Varnish (a really cool HTTP accelerator that I won't even try to explain here). Last, and certainly not least, is their customer service. I've grown accustomed to waiting 12-24 hours for support emails to be answered (being in Tokyo has a lot to do with the time delay). This is not the case with 45Air. So far they haveÂ replied very quickly to all of my inquiries and support requests, sometimes even when it was after midnight Pacific Standard Time. The folks that I've talked to have always offered real world replies too. There is no copy and pasting of pre-formatted scripts coming from their office - which is certainly refreshing. For the tech savvy folks out there 45Air also offers full SSH access (something that I've grown quite fond of actually), WP-CLI support, and for developers GIT based staging and version control with the plugin VersionPress Now that I've made the switch to 45Air I'm saving money, getting a lot more value for my money, and I'm not always worrying about my site crashing. I would say the biggest weight off of my shoulders though is knowing that I have a great crew of Wordpress experts at my fingertips keeping my site online while I get to pursue other activities.
Today's post isÂ decidedly not Tenkara related. As with all of my GearÂ articles though I have not received any financial incentives to write it. I have done this of my own volition and because of my appreciation for the service(s) that 45AirÂ provides.Â

item.title: Tenkara Action on the Doshi River éå¿å·
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
Last week the weather was pretty nasty. Tropical Storm Haishen pushed high winds, lots of rain, and even a little bit of sleet/snow towards Miura Peninsula Japan! I took advantage of the down time to tie some flies and do some work on the backend of this site. While it was a productive week I didn't move to Japan to sit behind a computer. I was itching to get out into the mountains. With a week of beautiful weather in the forecast I pieced together an epic Tenkara trip that would include the Doshi River, Shikatome River, Narago River, Tama River, Otsunakidani River, Yanagisawa River, Otsunakidani River, and finally the Otaba River. It was going to be an epic three day Tenkara adventure. Day 1 We got on the road early to beat the morning rush hour traffic. Our early departure was a good callÂ and it only took us two hours to get to theÂ small village of Omurozasu å¤§å®¤æ. Omurozasu is located right on the beautiful Doshi River. It is hard to believe that Tokyo, the largest city in the world, is less than 50 miles away. There was only one other angler on the river when we arrived. He wasÂ very friendly and his english was better than mine. He had spent several years in Portland learning how to fly-fish and had fished many of the same rivers as my friend Cameron, so needless to say we hit it off. He showed us around and helped us get our fishing ticket. For a day of fishing on the Doshi River it only cost us Â¥1000 each!

Photo Credit: Cameron Kline

I would describe the Doshi River as medium sized river with lots of structure. There are numerous deep pools, mid river boulders, and various other prime fish habitat. To top it off there is a waterfall that is several hundred feet tall that plunges into the Doshi River right above Omurozasu. It is truly a beautiful spot! After five hours of fishing on the Doshi River we pushed on up the 413 towards the small village of Higashikanji æ±ç¥å°. There is a nice managed fishing operation that we wanted to check out. Unfortunately the owners car was parked out front but he was nowhere to be found. It was a Wednesday afternoon, he was probably out fishing :) It costs Â¥3900 for a day of fishing and there are numerous deep man-made pool or you can opt to fish the more natural section of river. It is stocked so you're pretty much guaranteed to catch a lot of fish. After a brief foray at the fish farm we turnedÂ off of Highway 413 and drove up RouteÂ 24. It was to be an introduction to the Japanese mountain driving standard. No matter what type of vehicle they are driving - 40 to 50 kmh over the posted speed limit is the norm and it doesn't matter how windy the road is either. They all drive like they're in a Formula One race. Combined with their love of cigarettes, copious amounts of sake, and mercury laden fish I am truly in awe at how healthy they all appear to be and how long they live. To crack the eternal youth conundrum scientists should take a long hard look at the Japanese genes. Having survived the harrowing drive along Route 24 we arrived in the quaint mountain city of TsuruÂ é½ç. TheÂ friendly fly-fisherman we had met earlier in the day had suggested we check out Shishidome on theÂ Shikatome River. It is a fishing area managed by the fishing store giant Tackle Berry. It was just outside of the city so we drove up to check it out. TheÂ Shikatome River is absolutely beautiful. Stands of Sugar Pines line the banks, there are deep pools, the water is crystal clear, and there are even a few man-made lakes. There are several picnic areas that you can rent to BBQ your days catch, camping spots, cabins to rent, they even have a small store and a bar overlooking the river. It's a little on the pricey side though - camping costs Â¥9000 and a day fishing ticket costs Â¥4500 per person. They offer pony rides and tennis as well as a nearby grass skiing park so there is plenty to do and it is in a gorgeous mountain valley. Day trips to Oshino and Mount Fuji are also easily accessed from here. It's a two and a half hour train ride from the Tokyo Station toÂ Higashikatsura Station and will cost Â¥4300 round trip. [gallery link="file" size="large" type="slideshow" ids="822,821,820,819,817"] Shishidome was a little out of our budget so we pushed on. Our goal was to find camping somewhere along Highway 411. To get there we took Route 139. We thought Route 24 driving was epic but the driving on Highway 139 wasÂ even more intimidating. Rather than try to keep up withÂ the locals we instead choseÂ to take a more leisurely pace and soak in the views. While the spring flowers have mostly come and gone in Yokosuka up in the mountains they are just starting. Entire hillsides are covered in blooming and budding trees. After a bit of driving we saw a sign for a fishing operation and turned off of Highway 139 and made our way up to the small mountain town ofÂ Suganuma èæ²¼ where we came across the Narago River Fishing Field. There was no one there but the owner. He was very young and a Tenkara angler as well! He was very excited to show us his exquisiteÂ Anglo & Company Setagaya Custom Design tenkara rod complete with a Tenkara USA bag! It only cost Â¥3300 yen to fish for the day but it was getting late and we still had to find a place to camp so after chatting with him for a bit we pushed on. [gallery link="file" size="large" type="slideshow" ids="815,818,816"] Safely on Highway 413 we began to look for a campsite. One after another was closed or out of business and we began to get a little worried. After a bit of searching though we found a place that was open - TheÂ Hikawa Camping Ground in the city ofÂ OkutamaÂ å¥¥å¤æ©. It was Â¥700 to park for the night and Â¥800 per person for tent camping. The tent camping is on the sandy bank of the Tama River, unfettered access toÂ some beautiful yet challenging fishing. We got our lines wet but didn't have much luck, a few strikes and missed sets. A spin reel fisherman must have thought we were going to go hungry that night, due to our bad luck, so when he left he gifted to us his day's catch! A large rainbow and two very small Yamame! My buddy is a vegetarian so I had them all to myself :P That night we sat around our roaring campfire and sipped on sake and chu-hi. It was the perfect end to a perfect day! item.title: The Headwaters of the Tama River
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
Day 2 Part I - Exploring the Headwaters of the Tama River

The sun woke me up right around 5:30am. I contemplated going back to sleep but the sound of the Tama RiverÂ flowing past our campsite beckoned me like a siren song. I crawled out of my sleeping bag and rubbing the sleep from my eyes I stumbled to the bank of the Tama River and began to cast. As I stood there with my fly tumbling down the river I marveled at the water flowing past me. This river had been flowing for millennia. It never stopped, it never took a break, it never grew tired, it was always yearning and straining to break free of the land and enter the ocean. Much like a heart, it just kept going even when darkness settled upon the land the river kept flowing. I began to wonder Where was this river born? Where did she begin her journey to the ocean?Â 

I was jolted from my caffeine deprived reflections by the screech of a train far above me. The Chuo Line was headed to Tokyo, carrying her cargo of passengers to the bowels of an office building far far away. I imagined them in the train gazing out the window and seeing me on the bank of the river, with one hand in my pocket and the other grasping my trusty Tenkara rod. Instantly I knew that while their trajectory was taking them away from the mountains mine was taking me deeper into the heart of the mountains. To the place where the Tama was born. I collapsed my rod and headed back to camp to look at a map.

[gallery size="large" link="none" columns="1" ids="801"]

The heart of the Tama River is on the flank of Mount Karamatsu-Oyama. It was from this mountain that many streams were born, converging, and growing until they became the Tama and eventually the Pacific Ocean. After making breakfast and purchasing another nights stay at the Hikawa Campground we set off. The drive up highway 411 was pleasant. It was a beautiful day. Clear blue skies, not a cloud in sight, and a cool breeze blowing the scent of spring through the air. As we climbed higher into the mountains the road became narrower and narrower. There were more hairpin turns and tunnels. And then there she was, Mount Karamatsu-Oyama! We turned off the highway onto a road barely wide enough for one car. Springs were seeping from the mountainside as my car struggled in the thin mountain air.

This is where the Tama River is born! I felt like I was in a holy place. The mountain was awakening from her long winters hibernation and there was electricity in the air. We rounded a bend in the road and were greeted by a waterfall hardly visible through the bare trees. During the summer when the trees are green I bet you cannot even see the waterfall from the road. We were at the confluence of the Otsunakidani River and the Tasubamidani River.

[gallery link="none" size="large" columns="1" ids="802" orderby="rand"]

We found a small turn-out to park and headed down a faint path to the rivers edge. The river bed was a jumble of monstrous boulders, deep plunge pools, and sheer cliffs slowly crumbling against the onslaught of the river and the elements. The river was teeming with fish. They were staying down deep though. The water was frigid and traces of snow could still be seen in the shadows. We spent many hours stalking from pool to pool and piecing together hair raising descents down water polished boulders and cliff faces to reach the more enticing pools. The fishing pressure was readily apparent as tackle and line could be seen dangling from many low hanging branches. We came across a group of anglers and inquired about a fishing ticket. Apparently there was no need for a fishing ticket this far up in the mountains. It was unregulated and as far as we could tell no stocking operations filled the creek on a regular basis.

In our excitement to reach the headwaters of the Tama we had neglected to stock up on food. After ignoring our growling stomachs as long as we could we gave in to our hunger pangs and set off to find a place to eat.

To Be Continued...

item.title: Discovering the Yanagisawa River æ³æ²¢å·
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
Day 2 Part II

If you missed Day 2 Part I check it outÂ here

After a long drive up and over the Yanagisawa Pass we arrived in the town of Koshu. We found a Lawsons Convenience Store and gorged ourselves on some delicious grub. It was warm bordering on hot in Koshu and we were glad to escape back into the mountains with our food coffers replenished. On the way to Koshu we had passed the headwaters of the Yanagisawa River. It looked inviting so on the return trip we pulled over and descended into the bamboo thickets to the rivers edge. It was the quintessential small mountain stream. I could have really used a zoom rod though as the low hanging branches and dense foliage on the banks made the upper sections of this river very difficult to fish. As I worked my way down stream the river opened up and there were some beautiful pools. After several hours of fishing the beautiful Yanagisawa River I had more luck catching branches than trout. With only one bite in a few hours we decided to push on.

[gallery link="none" columns="2" size="medium" ids="789,790"]

We continued on down the highway, slowly making our way back to camp. As we descended down the mountain the weather grew more ominous. The clouds grew darker and rain began to spit randomly from the grey sky. We could catch glimpses of the Yanagisawa River far below the highway. It was turning into a full blown river but the access looked hellish. I had left my rope at home so rappelling into the river bottom was not option. However, after a sharp hairpin turn we found a turn out right above the Yanagisawa River. It was an easy scramble down to the river. The Yanagisawa had grown exponentially and we worked our way upstream fishing large pools and side stepping trees torn apart by massive avalanches from the harsh winter. As we continued up our way was blocked by an impassable waterfall. The waterfall had, over countless years, carved out a huge pool and a massive eddy. I tied on a bead head midge and dropped it into the cloudy water from atop a boulder perched on the edge of the pool. I had numerous bites and one fish on but only for a second. As the eddy pulled my line through the water in a continuous circle the fish began to grow weary of my fly and the bites subsided. With darkness rapidly approaching I collapsed my rod and scrambled off of my perch and began to pick my way downstream, back to the car.

[gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="788,791,792"]

The Yanagisawa River had proven to be a challenging river. The whole day we were swarmed by hatches, flies, mayflies, and moths. Perhaps the fish were picky due to the smorgasbord flittering about the river or maybe it was the evident fishing pressure that had made these fish extra wary. Whatever the reason, the Yanagisawa River had bested us. As I sat by the crackling fire back at camp I was a little perturbed at being skunked. But as I remind myself where I was and had been, fishing in a beautiful Japanese mountain stream. And now I was camping on the Tama River sitting beneath a beautiful array of stars, I smiled and thanked God for another beautiful day. Suddenly it didnât matter that I hadnât caught a fish that day. I was just glad to be here right now, the saying âAny day on the river is better than one in a cubicle.â rang especially true in that moment.

item.title: A Day Hike On Miura Peninsula
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
Authors Note: I have decided to start a semi-regular segment chronicling my day to day life in Japan. Everything in JapanÂ is so different when compared to the United States, so I thought I would share with my readers my various experiences of living in Japan. It will be a catch all category, covering everything from baseball games in Tokyo, to skiing in Hakuba, to rock climbing in Jogasaki. So without further ado I present the first installment of "Life In Japan"Â A Day Hike OnÂ Miura Peninsula
In a few days Golden Week, which is the longest vacation period for many jobs in Japan, kicks off. The Japanese take full advantage of the long vacation and travel. Finding lodging anywhere in Japan during this week is nearly impossible. If you want to brave the traffic and travel during this week you should make reservations many months in advance if not years. There are many holiday days packed into Golden Week. One of those holiday days is Tango no Sekku, or Boys Day (this year Tango no SekkuÂ is May 5th). To commemorate the holiday the Japanese fly a koinobori banner for each one of the children in their family. A koinobori is a banner shaped like a carp. In Japanese folklore, the carp is a symbol of determination and vigor, overcoming all obstacles to swim upstream. I decided to take advantage of the perfect spring weather today and go for a hike before the swarms of holiday crowd descend on the local trails. I chose an area called Takatori, which is located on Miura Peninsula. As I pulled into the trailhead parking lot I could see that preparations for Childrens Day wereÂ already underway. There were close to one hundredÂ koinobori banners hung above the trailhead with many more waiting to be strung up. [gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="951,950,952"] As I continued up into the forest I passed by a small bonsai tree nursery. There are probably 40-50 bonsai trees sitting on tables. TheÂ curator lives in a small shack heated by a wood burning stove that sits on the edge of a small mountain stream that terminates into a nice pond. When I think of a quintessential bonsai tree nursery I think of this place.Â The trail quickly climbs up out of the valley and as IÂ crest onto the ridgeline I amÂ greeted with a cluster of BuddhistÂ temples. They are closed right now so I press on up the trail. [gallery columns="2" size="medium" link="none" ids="955,956"] Once IÂ climbed up to the top of small mountain behind the BuddhistÂ temples the trail followed the ridgeline and leveled out for awhile. In a few places the trail got pretty sketchy though and I hadÂ to cling to a shinyÂ chain bolted to the rock face/trail to preventÂ myselfÂ from falling down the vertical hillside. The trail access an area with numerousÂ large rock formation called Takatori Yama. This area is popular with rock climbers and features many rock climbing routes. Check out the area page on Mountain ProjectÂ for more details. [gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="957,958,967"] Today I hiked into an area I had never been. In the past I had assumed that the trail went straight into a neighborhood and wasn't worth the hike. While I was right about the trail going into a neighborhood I did discover several rock faces that make it worth going just a little further on the trail. With a quick detour through a neighborhood I regained the trail and continued my exploration and cameÂ across many ancient Buddha rock art and sculptures. This area is packed with culture and history! [gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="965,964,966"] With the hottest part of the day approaching and with the humidity seemingly increasing by the second I set a course for home. As I made my down the trail back to my car I marveled at my first spring in Japan. The bird song in the forest was deafening at times and the flowers were in fullÂ bloom. The forest is coated in bright shades of green and the warm air is welcomed after a long, windy, and frigid winter. It's hard to believe that just a few weeks ago it was in the high 30's and sleeting. Much like the mid-Atlantic region of the US spring does not pussy foot its way in the door - it kicks the door down and screams "Honey I'm HOME!". I just smile and say Where have you been? and mutter under my breath But please don't melt all the snow too fast though, I still want to go skiing... Subscribe to Fallfish Tenkara by Email Random Fact March 3 is Hinamatsuri, or Girls Day. However, Hinamatsuri and Tango no Sekku have been lumped together and the day typically reserved for Boys DayÂ is nowÂ called Kodomo no Hi or Childrens Day. Still, during HinamatsuriÂ the young ladiesÂ get dressed up in their fanciest Kimono, do up their hair and makeup and go out on the town. It's quite a sight to behold.

item.title: A Day on the Otaba River - å¤§ä¸¹æ³¢å·
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
As I reflect back on the three days I spent in the Kanto Mountain Range (é¢æ±å±±è) the highlight for me was the last day which was spent exploring Otaba River (a special thanks toÂ Ridgeline ImagesÂ for his fortuitous comment which put this river on my radar). After some research I realized that the Kanto Mountains trip I was planning was going to be very close to the Otaba River. Naturally I had to check it out!

On the morning of the third day we arose with the sun and headed down to the Tama to fish before breakfast. My buddy caught a beautiful Yamame from a large pool and I had a fish on but she got off. It was a good sign for the day to come (especially since the Tama had bested us for the past two days). We took down camp and made several trips with our camping gear up the steep road from the river to our car. The parking lot is perched on the hillside in the midst of a collection of quaint cabins available for rent, if sleeping in a tent isn't your thing.

[gallery link="none" columns="2" size="medium" ids="985,986"] After we finished packing up and settling our parking bill, we stopped by the local Hemlock Coffee Shop to get our caffeine fix, but they weren't open until noon so we suppressed our craving for caffeine and headed over to Hikawa International Fishing Spot (æ°·å·å½éé£ãå ´). The facilities are very nice and there are numerous man made pools and natural river sections to catch stocked Brook, Rainbow and Yamame trout from. It costs Â¥3200 for a one day fishing ticket. Unfortunately they do not allow Tenkara. It was not readily apparent why, but they are happy provide bamboo rods for an extra charge (Â¥300 I believe). After looking around for a bit we headed back to our car and made our way to the Otaba River. [gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="988,987,989"]

Turning off Highway 413 onto route 202 I was struck by the small village of Otaba juxtaposedÂ  against the backdrop of the rugged mountains. Down low the Otaba River hardly looks like a mountain stream. The valley is a complex maze of roads and homes improbably balanced on the hillside. However, as we continued up the 202 the valley constricted and the homes began to thin out. Soon we were surrounded by forest and wasabi farms planted in the small streams seeping from the mountainside. We found a three car turnout and parked. On the other side of the road was a faint path down to the river. There were numerous deep pools, waterfalls, and even some huge boulders which apparently have a few climbing routes on them. I began making my way upstream and fishing the plethora of pools. There were a lot of fish in the river including many 3-5cm long fingerlings.

[gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="991,993,994"]

As the day progressed I landed two small Yamame! The first was in the first pool I fished that day and the second was in a large pool below a small waterfall. Ounce for ounce they are a very ferocious fish. Their acrobatic display when hooked is quite impressive and reminded me of the native Brown Trout I caught in the spring fed creeks of Frederick County Maryland. Both slipped off my barbless hooks though before I could finagle my camera out of my pack.Â After a half dayÂ of fishing on the Otaba (boy does time fly when you Tenkara fly fish huh?) it was time to make our way home before the Friday evening rush hour traffic became intolerable. The transition from the mountains into the urban sprawl of Tokyo was abrupt. Every fiber of my being was straining to turn the car around and get lost in the Kanto Mountain Range all over again. But we both had responsibilities that could not be shirked any longer. The drive back home was largely spent in silence. As I watched the mountains fade into the haze through my rearview mirror, I was simultaneously looking forward to a shower and wishing I could spend just one more night camped out under the stars on the bank of the Tama River. I consoled myself with the knowledge that this little piece of heaven was less than two hours from my home and that I could visit whenever I wanted.

item.title: Japanese Cuisine
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded: Warning! If you are hungry, eat something before viewing this post. You have beenÂ warned! Since moving to Japan in the fall of 2014 I have become quite the connoisseur of the cornucopia of Japanese cuisine options. EverythingÂ is absolutely delectable. I have yet to have a bad meal here in Japan. The dedication to preparing good food in Japan is extraordinary. For example, I have heard a rumor that there is a Japanese food truck somewhere in the vicinity of Mount Fuji where the owner moved to Mexico for three years to learn how to cook Mexican food. After his long tutelage in Mexico he moved back to Japan and now makes the most amazing tacos you have ever tasted... In Japan! When I find it, I'll be sure to let y'all know. The same attention to detail that Japanese Tenkara anglers apply to their craft is given to preparing food in Japan - and it is readily apparent in pretty much any establishment you have the pleasure of dining in. Here are a few of the 'crowning moments'Â from my dining experience in Japan. [gallery link="file" size="full" columns="2" type="carousel" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="1039,1040,1041,1045,1046,1047,1048,1049,1050,1051,1062,1061,1060,1057,1056,1053,1052,1063,1064"] Everyday in Japan is an adventure. Even going toÂ the local Japanese grocery store, and browsing through all the food, can be an adventure. I always enjoy perusingÂ the shelves to see what interesting items are available. Here are a few of the highlights... item.title: Doshi River at the Sasakune Village
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded: The weather last week wasÂ absolutely spectacular. Low humidity, temps in the mid 70's, and lots of sunshine. It felt like a crime to not be out and about in the mountains. So when my alarm woke me up at 4am on Friday, I was giddy with excitement. The sun was already coming up as I brewed up my coffee and fried up some eggs and hash browns. The drive to the river seemed to take longer than usual with a lot of drivers on the road. But finally we escaped the Tokyo traffic and made our way through the mountains towards theÂ small village of Sasakune. The village is nestled below a waterfall and tucked into a small meadow dotted with vegetable gardens and surrounded by tall mountains shrouded in bamboo and cedar forests. [gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="1098,1099,1100" orderby="rand"] The fishing ticket sales are sold out of a fishing collective volunteers home. We felt bad knocking on hisÂ door at 7:30am and especially bad when the owner answered the door in his pajamas. There was some sort of problem with Mastercard that morning so I had been unable to get Â¥ at the ATM so I had to pay for my ticket with a handful of coins. The gentlemen who sold us the tickets was both amused and annoyed at having to count so many coins before his morning tea... With much bowing and "gomen'nasai's" on my behalf I collected my fishing ticket and headed to the river. [gallery link="none" size="medium" columns="2" ids="1102,1103" orderby="rand"] The last time I had been here the river was teaming with fish. While there were fish in the river today there was a noticeable decline in activity and many of the fish we did see were pretty small. Our concerns thatÂ this area had been pretty popular during Golden Week were confirmed. The fish, that had been lucky enough to survive the onslaught, were still recovering from the pressure. After four hours of absolutely no action, I was getting desperate. I had tried every kebari in my arsenal, even my go to flies that had always worked in the past were getting no love. Out of desperation I tied on a #14 terrestrial with a meter or so of 7x and then things got interesting! My first cast the fly had barely touched the water and a fish came out of no where and hit the fly hard. I missed the set but a few casts later I had a fish on! But after a bit of a fight she got off. Yamame are very challenging fish to catch. They are very adept at getting off the hook. [gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="1104,1105,1106" orderby="rand"] All told we spent 11 hours on the river, andÂ we brought one fish to hand, had about 1/2 a dozen on our line who got loose, and about a dozen bites - all on terrestrials. Easily the most challenge day of fishing I had ever experienced. We had prepared ourselves for this though as we knew that Golden Week had just wrapped up. In fact we were quite surprised there were any fish left in the river at all. We saw five or six keiryu anglers throughout the day and they did not appear to be catching anything either, and they were using bait... [gallery link="none" columns="2" size="medium" ids="1108,1109" orderby="rand"] As you can see from the photos though it was an absolutely gorgeous day. I wet waded most of the day because the water was the perfect temperature. No need for waders and when the wind blew and the puffy white clouds temporarily blotted out the sun I would retreat to a warm sandy beach and watch the butterflies. I explored a huge section of the river, probably walking a total of 4 miles, up and down the river and exploring the creeks that flowed into the Doshigawa. I didn't want the day to end but alas with the last rays of sunlight we headed home. We stopped at aÂ 7 Eleven, on the way back, and gorged ourselves on broccoli & shrimp egg salad, edamame, Japanese doria (rice gratin), SpriteÂ made with real sugar(!), and vegetables dipped in a spicy mayonnaise sauce. Despite the lack of fish it was still a great day on a phenomenal river. [kad_youtube url="https://youtu.be/P2KLkz4pLsg" width=560 height=315 ] Subscribe to Fallfish Tenkara by Email

item.title: Yamabirugawa
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded: I have numerousÂ things on my "to-do" list while living inÂ Japan. For example, I've skied Japan's famous powder and I've gotten lost in Tokyo. But there are several more "to-do's" that I haven't accomplished yet. Climbing Mount Fuji and skiing from the summit for example. The other day I ticked another "to-do" off the list - Tenkara fly-fish a remote headwaters in the mountains of Japan and catch native Yamame. I must say that it is pretty cool toÂ discover a remote river that sees little human encroachment and besides a few distant power lines and weirs there is no sign of man - just mountains covered in trees erupting in their spring glory! After thoroughly scoping the area on Google Maps I decided to see what the fishing was like. First I had to navigate a very narrow winding mountain highway.Â At the trailhead asÂ I was changing out of my hiking boots into my bike riding shoes I noticed I had gotten some mud on my hand. When I tried to wipe it off it wouldn't come off. Upon closer inspection I realized I had a land leech stuck to my hand! This was my first experience with leeches and I must say it was pretty gross. There are now two things I hate in this world: spiders and leeches. After plucking the leech off I went down to the creek to rinse my boots off and came across a giant Japanese Mountain Leech. This bad boy doesn't suck blood, rather it eats earth worms and snails... There are some interesting videos on YouTube - Google at your own peril though... The Japanese Mountain Leech is referred to as theÂ yamabiru in Japan. The literal translation is Mountain Beer - seems a little odd to me. I certainly felt like drinking a beer after being bit by one so maybe that is how they got their name... After dealing with the leeches I transitioned to my mountain bike for a three mile ride along a logging/fire road to the river. [gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="1136,1134,1135"] But leeches or not I had come to see if there were any native trout in this creek. Yamabirugawa (real name redacted to protect this natural area from being overrun)Â is the quintessential mountain stream - perfect for Tenkara, and as I had hoped was teeming with trout! Every pool I fished I got a bite or five! I'll tell you though that Yamame are adept at getting off your line. I've read up on the Yamame on a few Japanese blogs and apparently they have perfected the technique of log rolling in the water. This is apparently a successful maneuverÂ for getting off the hook. The first fish was fairly big and when he had loaded my rod to a nice bend he popped off the hook and my fly went flying into a distant tree branch where it will be for some time to come. With my lucky fly gone I tied on another terrestrial, only slightly bigger. I thought the larger size would detract from its effectiveness but the fish loved it even more! I tried a new technique I had read about, where you high stick your rod above the water and in small quick movements you lift the fly off the surface of the water and quickly drop it back onto the surface of the water. This mimics a bug, like a mayfly, landing on the water surface to lay eggs before flying off to avoid becoming a tasty snack for a hungry trout. My fly got slammed by at least three trout with this technique including a very large one. They all missed though and after awhile the gig was up and the fish stopped going for the terrestrial fly. So I sat down on the bank and observed the fish for a bit. I noticed they were rising a lot to eat bugs floating on the surface. I had fished dry flies before but had never had any luck. I figured I had nothing to loose so I retreated back to my pack and tied on my #18 parachute dry fly (purchased at Savage River Outfitters). After a few practice casts to get a nice drift a beautiful 5" Yamame slammed it hard and I brought her to hand! I was stoked. My first wild mountain native Yamame - and I was 35 miles from Tokyo! I continuedÂ downstream after releasing the Yamame searching for a new pool to try my luck, instead I cameÂ across a weir. [gallery link="none" size="medium" ids="1137,1138,1139"] After down climbing the ladder on the side of the weir I continued downstream, fishing the small pools and spotting many more trout. After descending further downstream I came upon yet another weir, this one was bigger than the last and the ladder deposited you on the side of a cliff above a very deep pool. It looked pretty technical and time consuming and with three hours of hiking, biking, and driving ahead of me to get home I decided it would be prudent to head home. The Yamabirugawa is very extensive creek. I am hoping to return with overnight gear and spend a few days exploring it in its entirety. Here is a video I put together of the days adventures.
