Groundstore a Tenkara shop in Tokyo is only a 5 minute walk from Fuda Station. This lifestyle shop carries Tenkara gear and brews great coffee too

item.title: Sugegasa
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
On the way home from my recent fishing trip in Nagano, my buddy and I stopped in at a locally made goods shop. I was looking for one thing in particular, a sugegasa (èç¬ ) - also known as a conical bamboo hat. Well lucky for me they had a bunch in stock! While the sweet obichan behind the counter was customizing the hat to fit my huge head I perused the shelves. Tucked in the back corner I came across a dusty box filled with wooden hand carved figurines. In the backÂ of the box,Â I came across a hand carved and painted Iwana figurine. It was love at first site. I think they look pretty good together :D The head basket is a little itchy so I wear a bandana, pirate style, on my head. The sugegasa is surprisingly cool and quite comfortable too. I did knock the hat a few times on low branches due to the fact that it sticks a good 12cm above the top of my head. So there will be a slight learning curve with my new headgear. After watching thisÂ video I may start referring to myself as "The blonde beard who lives life with nature" :) Anyways clothed in my Montbell fishing knickers, sawanobori gear, and now my sugegasa I am fully immersing myself into the Japanese Tenkara clothing style as made by popular by the great Sebata-san and Kado-sanÂ (my Tenkara sensei). I have yet to adopt the waders that Dr. Ishigaki and Masami typically wear. However, my fishing skill is still a long ways off from any of them. This was made especially clear to me during my recent fishing trip. [caption id="attachment_3916" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] A long abandoned bridge stands an 'eternal' watch over the entrance to a keiryu paradise[/caption] There is a network of valleys I have long wanted to explore, but being an extra hours drive away from where I normally go I have put it off. Until yesterday. In an effort to save Â¥5000 in tolls I avoided the highways and took surface streets though. At 0500 in the morning the journey was quick and painless. However, getting home that night would prove to be pretty tedious. After a few hours of driving I turned up a windy mountain road, but after about 20 minutes of driving I realized that there wasn't a convenience store in this valleyÂ (they do have three car dealerships though). So begrudgingly I turned around and headed back into town to buy breakfast and lunch.Â As I drove back up into the mountains I came across hundreds of tents pitched on every flat section of river and all theÂ campgrounds were filled to max capacity. I had overlooked the fact that the day beforeÂ was the newly created Mountain Day holiday. Consequently folks descend into the mountains in droves for the four day weekend. As I've come to discover fishing during a national holiday is a really bad idea. The rivers can take a week if not a full season to fully recover from the decimation that descends upon themÂ from the stampede of anglers. Since I was already there though I keptÂ my fingers crossed that I'd luck out. [gallery link="file" columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="3918,3919,3920,3922,3924"] As I made my way up the river, I did see a lot of small Yamame and maybe even an Iwana or two. There was also severalÂ sets of footprints in the gravel banks by the river. Still the fish were biting and I had several fish that got off when I was reaching for them (I really do need to get a tamo). I did touch one though as he flopped back into the water so at least I caught one. The frustrating part of the day was that every third cast or so I would get my line caught in a tree branch. My casting technique was off the whole day, which was weird. I couldn't get the presentation or accuracy that I wanted and I was constantly getting snags, tangles, and losing flies. Right as I was about to turn around in frustration I came around a bend and saw a spectacular waterfall. It wasn't on my map, which I thought was pretty cool. A "secret" waterfall! By happenchanceÂ I discovered a 5th class route up the side of the waterfall that was completely invisible from below. Above the waterfall there were many beautiful cascades and huge plunge pools. After fishingÂ upstream for a bit I turned around because there were still a few other rivers I wanted to explore.

The second river I just wasn't feeling and gave up fishing after 20 minutes or so. It was right next to a trail and I suspected that it had seen a lot of pressure over the last few days. On the way back to the car I came across a small tributary. It looked promising so I went to take a closer look. Almost immediately there was a weir that was pretty tall and blocking my upriver progress. But there was a tree growing next to it, so I climbed the tree to surmount the dam. A short ways up the river there was another weir that had an old rusty ladder built into it. Still above the second weir was yet another weir. This one required a bit of waterfall climbing to surmount. Before I climbed it though I doubled back to the previousÂ weir and recovered an old rope I had found there.

[caption id="attachment_3941" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] The second weir I came across on the third river I fished. Note the rope that I fixed for the descent. The weir is about 5-6 meters tall[/caption] The river above these three weirs was awesome. There were perfect pools every 5-10 meters, there was almost no low foliage, and the water was very cold. However, I didn't see a single fish or even get a single bite. I did come across an old campsite and aÂ very corroded Tenkara line and fly, so obviously the river had fish in it at one point. It has been a very dry summer for Japan without a single typhoon having hit the Tokyo region. Last year there was a good 15-20 typhoons by this time last summer. Consequently, a lot of the rivers around here are lower than normal. Lake Miyagase is emptying rapidly. Perhaps last year was an anomaly and maybe this is just a normal summer, because no one seems to be overly worried about it. Whatever the case is I could tell that this river was flowing at a less than normal rate. Perhaps the fish had migratedÂ downstream to bigger water. I am not sure really. While it was a fun river to fish it was a little sad not to see any residents inÂ the river. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" ids="3943,3944,3945,3946" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""] I really like fishing small water in Japan, so I was bummed to not see any fish. God willing I'll head back next season just to check and make sure that there aren't any fish here.
Lastly, here are a few photos from my fishing trip last week. The river was absolutely loaded with fish. I caught about a dozen Yamame and Iwana throughout the day using the fly that Yamada-san gave me. item.title: Susuki
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
The Silver Grass Autumn Flower

Every year in late August the head high grass called susuki (ããã) blooms en-mass. The soft goldÂ grass "flowers" are quite beautiful despite their lackluster coloring. It is always a little sad to see the susuki blooming though as it signals the rapidly approaching end to the mountain stream fishing season. With only five weeks left, I am planning some cool tripsÂ for September. This past week though I took full advantage of the pleasant summer weather and headed to Niigata Prefecture,Â with my Tenkara sensei Kado-san, for a four day/three night Tenkara trip! [caption id="attachment_3962" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Blooming Susuki (ããã) grass[/caption]
Night one we drove deep into the mountains until the road turned to dirt and was blocked by a gate. We pitched our tent on the shoulder of the road while the frogs jumped through the grass and from the trees overhead. The moon was shining brightly, it was hard to believe that just three hours away tropical storm Kompasu was dumping lots of rain throughout the Tokyo region. We retired late at around 0200 and were awake five hours later to make Royal Tea and to dine on a quick camp breakfast. Stuffed on a delicious breakfast courtesy of 7-11 we plunged into the forest towards the siren song of running water. The storm clouds had been building all morning and shortly afterÂ we had both caught and released our first Iwanas the skies opened up. It was one of the hardest rains I had experienced in Japan, we were both a little concerned with floods. Thankfully though the rain let up and assuaged our fears of a flash flood. After the rain the fishing really picked up and we were catching and seeing a lot of fish. Due to the rain and dripping trees I didn't get very many photos though (I really need to get a waterproof camera). [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="mosaic" ids="3965,3966,3967,3968" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""] Around 2pm we packed up our Tenkara rods and plunged into the jungle and bushwacked our way up a steep hillside towards an old logging road. Safely back on the "road" we made our way back to camp. The previous night's camp was only temporary, Kado-san had found a much better place to camp on a recent scouting trip. On the way to our new campsiteÂ the clouds parted, the sun came out, and we caught a glimpse of the picturesque Japanese valley below! Our campsite for the second and third nights was a tad overgrown so we had to hack out a lot of brush with Kado-san's nata (ãªã). [gallery columns="2" size="full" link="file" type="default" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="3970,3971"] The campsite was right on the Kamagawa (éå·) near Tashiro (ç°ä»£), I fished the river for a bit but the water was fairly warm and the fishing wasn't great so I went swimming instead. It was pretty humid, even sitting around camp you were soon covered in sweat. So the dunk in the river was very much appreciated. That night we hid out under the awning while spot storms spit rain on us throughout the night. [caption id="attachment_3982" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Sunset on night two[/caption] The next morning we were up bright and early. After a lazy morning we drove deeper into the mountains, donned our fishing clothing, and made our way further up the "road" on foot. After a very hot and muggy 45 minute hike we arrived at the river. Almost immediately we spotted fish but they weren't to interested in our flies. After hiking up stream for a bit we came across a very narrow gorge choked with boulders. We had to do a bit of climbing, scrambling, and spelunking to get around. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="3974,3975,3976,3977,3979,3983,3984,3985"] I love adventure fishing, it is one of the reasons why I have fallen in love with Tenkara. The mountains in Japan are a veritable paradise of small streams that are found in some of the most wild and stupendous locations. About two hours into the day,Â I was fishing aÂ promising spot when a wild boar spotted us and plunged into the river and into the forest just in frontÂ of us. It happened so quickly that Kado-san didn't see it. Still I'm not sure if it was wild boar, it could have been a bear. For the rest of the day we stayed within eyesight of each other, just to be safe. [caption id="attachment_3980" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Streamside somen! oishii desu![/caption] After stopping to make somen for lunch we began looking for a way around an impassable waterfall. Eventually we found a route around that required a hundred meters or so of class V rock climbing to getÂ above and around the waterfall. The climbing was easy, maybe 5.1, but the adventure was thrilling. Safely back in the river above the waterfall Kado-san and I were giggling like schoolgirls with glee. The fishing above the waterfall was great but not in the way you would expect. We only caught one fish, but we did see a lot of large fish. However, they all seemed to be spawning - about 6 weeks early actually. Kado-san told me that when Iwana spawn this early it means that the winter is going to be cold and long :D [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Spawning Iwana (hard to make out, there's actually two)[/caption] After fishing for another hour or so, we turned around and made the long and difficult journey back to camp. [gallery size="full" type="carousel" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="3987,3986,3988"] The next day we were pretty beat from two days of very physical Tenkara fly fishing and in desperate need of a nice soak in an onsen. So we packed up camp and made our way back to civilization. On the way we stopped and explored a few rivers for possible destinations next time. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" ids="3989,3990,3991,3992,3993" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""] This had been the first time that Kado-san and I had been fishing together this season due to family health issues. It was great to get back into the mountains with my friend. Every trip we go on is better than the last (I really don't know how he does it!). On the way back towards Tokyo we started makingÂ plans for theÂ next fishing trip in September, a three day backpacking trip - similar to what we did last year.

item.title: Blue and White Flycatcher ãªãªã«ãª
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
The mountains of Japan are a natural aviary, the perfect rest stop for migratory birds. TheÂ ãªãªã«ãª(Oruri) also known as theÂ Blue and White Flycatcher, is one of those migratoryÂ birds that makes the mountains of Japan its summer home.Â Due to the harsh winter climate in Japan they fly south to the Philippines inÂ October and return to the Land of the Rising Sun in earlyÂ April. Photo Â© Wikipedia Japan While I have seen a lot of ãªãªã«ãªOruri flying about before I had never heard themÂ sing. That was until last week when my friend and I went on a scouting trip to a remote upper headwater in the Tanzawa Mountains. I think their song is quite beautiful and very striking. [playlist tracklist="false" artists="false" images="false" ids="4065"] This particular keiryu is tucked away deep in the mountains, a tiny tributaryÂ the KouchigawaÂ æ²³åå·. The lower half of this remote keiryu cuts through aÂ very steep and narrow canyon. Within the first kilometer or so there are over 50 waterfalls! Based upon the trip reports I came across the valley is quiteÂ popular with sawanobori folks. However, my friend and I didn't have the gear nor the expertise to tackle the lower half. So I did some research and found mention of a seldom traveled foot path that skirted around the technical section to the less often visited upper portion of the river. This "path" started around 550 meters and summited three peaks culminating at 1031 meters before descending into a side canyon. It looked simple enough, a lot of elevation gain but it looked doable. So the night before our adventure I set my alarm forÂ 0400 as toÂ capitalize on the cooler morning temperatures for the hike in. The next morning we departed Yokosuka at around 0515 and about two hours laterÂ we arrived at the "trailhead". We parked our car by the gate, donned our gear, and peddled our bikes up the closed road. After a pleasantÂ ride we stashedÂ the bikes in the forest and descended to the river where we located the bypassÂ "trail". Before we began the climb though we filled our bellies with water and one canteen for the hike. It was going to be a while before we came across another water source. [caption id="attachment_4070" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] ãªãªã«ãª(Oruri) territory[/caption] The first two peaks came and went without a hitch. The trail disappeared and reappeared numerous times but following the topography and a map with a GPS track overlay that I had found the going was fairly straightforward. However, after summiting the second peak the terrain became much more overgrown. Thankfully we had the pleasant bird calls of theÂ ãªãªã«ãªOruri to keep us company though. The fun was still to come howeverÂ because between the secondÂ and third peak was a distinct notch marked with some very tight lines on the topo map. My research had mentioned ropes but it didn't look that bad from the few grainy photos I could find. When we got to the ropes I realized that I was grossly misinformed. [caption id="attachment_4071" align="aligncenter" width="768"] Have sugegasa will climb![/caption] The pucker factor was as high as the vertical hillside covered in a thin vernier of disintegrating sandstone. But after putting in a solid two hour effort to get this far we weren't going to be deterred from our goal. Thankfully the ropes looked pretty new and someone had been kind enough to tie a lot of knots in them so the climbing was easy, as long as you didn't look down. Safely onÂ the other side - the climb to the top of the last unnamed peak was easy, compared to what we had just surmounted. Unfortunately on the decent we took the wrong ridge line into the river valley. We ended up in a narrow slot canyon above several "too big to safely down climb" waterfalls that required a dicey traverse to bypass. By the time we made it to the river, some three and a half hours after starting we were thoroughly exhausted butÂ ready to fish! [caption id="attachment_4076" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] First view of water after an epic hike![/caption] After drinking greedily from the river and eating a few onigiri we pulled out our rods and began fishing the promising pools. The water was still pretty high from Typhoon Lionrock which had swept through a few days prior but clear. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="mosaic" ids="4074,4072,4073,4075" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""] The sun was high in the sky and there wasn't much cloud cover so I was taking care to move slow and watch my shadows. At a promising pool I was casting half blind behind a large boulder relying onÂ feel alone to detect a strike. My latest rod acquisition, the very supple Nissin Pro-Square Mulch 360 made this easy. I felt a slight tug and set the hook. There was a loud snap and then something hit my sugegasa with a loud thunk. Suddenly my rod felt light in my hand, and then I saw my rod tip floating away downstream. The fish had broken my rod. Dejected I reached down and grabbed my rod tip with the line still attached to the lillian. My sadness turned to elation though because as I brought in the line I realized I still had a fish on! Somehow she had not managed to get off. Perhaps the rod tip floating downstream had kept enough tension on the line to keep the fly in her jaw. Or maybe it was just a blessed day (a hard to deny distinct possibility after surviving the approach unscathed). [caption id="attachment_4079" align="aligncenter" width="768"] The little beauty that broke my favorite rod :([/caption] Thankfully I had packed a second rod, so my day wasn't shot and we continued fishing - leapfrogging up the valley, each of us taking a turn at every other promising pool. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="4080,4081,4082,4083,4084,4092"] The river was absolutely beautifulÂ and it wasn't long before we came across the Garden of Eden of pools, which just so happened to be my friends pool to fish. Where he hooked one of the biggest Iwana I had ever seen! And then we released him... [caption id="attachment_4087" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Good bye little buddy - make sure you spawn a lot this fall.[/caption] The approach had taken longer than we had suspected. So unfortunately we only had about 4 hours to fish before it was time to begin our egress with enough daylight to make it safely back to the car. As if by a miracle, my buddyÂ stumbled acrossÂ a much more straightforward route back to the car. This alternate route option gave us both a sigh of reliefÂ as we were not looking forward to reversing the slog we had undertaken to get there. Once was enough. On the hike back the ãªãªã«ãª(Oruri) were silent, instead of their pleasant songs we were serenaded by the eerie wines from a herd of deer. [caption id="attachment_4091" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] We got back to the car just in time to catch a spectacular sunset.[/caption]

item.title: Hachijojima
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
Back in JulyÂ my friend Junpei asked me if I wanted to go to a Japanese music festival on Hachijojima, a tiny island off the coast of Japan. The musicÂ festivalÂ called Liquid Groove Drop, was a mix of Indian music, techno, and elctronic danceÂ music. The venue was theÂ Yokotoike Ura Beach (æ¨ªåã¶æµ¦) on the west side of the island. I was intrigued and after doing some research on the island I emphatically said "YES!"
  • Hachijojima (å«ä¸å³¶) is one of thirteen Izu Islands that are located in the Philippine Sea off the east coast of Japan.
  • Nine of these islands are populated, Hachijojima being one of the largest and the only one with an airport that offers regular flights.
  • HachijojimaÂ is a popular destination for scuba divers and snorkelers as the Kuroshio Current keeps the water very warm.
  • In the 50's and 60's Japan promoted the island as the "Hawaii of Japan".
  • With nearly 60km of coastline, much of it inaccessible due to huge sea cliffs, and two large volcanos on each end of the island - the area is rife with natural beauty.
You can get to the island either via ANA which has three flights a day from Haneda Airport or via an overnight ferry. The ferry departs at 10:30pm from Tokyo and arrives at 8:50am the next day. Our friend chose the ferry while my wife and I splurged and got a plane ticket. While the island has a lot of options for lodging we chose the free camping option. At first we were planning on camping at the only campground on the island, but due to the event staff using the campground as living quarters the city opened upÂ Plaza Park (å«ä¸ãã©ã¶å¬å) for us to camp at. The park had a bathroom and a covered BBQ area with sinks which was nice. Typically you are not allowed to camp at the park but for the event the city made an exception. The free campground is located right next toÂ Sokotsuchi Beach (åºåæµ·æ°´æµ´å ´) which is an excellent place to snorkel - something that we did every day we were there. [caption id="attachment_4112" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Sokotsuchi Beach[/caption] The snorkeling is amazing on this island, the water is warm and we saw all manner of sea creatures swimming about in the coral reefs. I even pet a sea turtle that swam right up to me! My friend broughtÂ his spear and we tried to get a Yellowfin Tuna or two that we saw swimming about in huge schools, but they were too fast. I would have posted a lot of photos of the underwater paradise but our waterproof Nikon camera turned out to not be that waterproof. The next day we visitedÂ Uramigataki Onsen (æ¹¯è£è¦ã¶æ»æ¸©æ³) which is located at the confluence of theÂ Miharakawa (ä¸åå·) and the Yasukawa (å®å·) PDFÂ (original link). The Yasukawa flows from a nice looking lake. Perhaps it has fish in it? I am not sure because I didn't bring the right equipment for fresh water fishing (aka my Tenkara rod) as IÂ didnât think there were any rivers on the island besides a few seasonal drainages... I was wrong. [caption id="attachment_4115" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] The onsen is male and female - bathing suits mandatory. It sits between two waterfalls and a third one below the onsen.[/caption]   To get around the island we rented bicycles for Â¥1500 a day per person. One day we rented a car that cost Â¥3000 per day and Â¥1000 extra for optional insurance. The rental office is located in the Mobil Gas Station. They also rent scooters and go carts. The later is Â¥1000 per hour - I am not sure how much scooters cost to rent (also note the go carts don't come with a helmet...). The attendant spoke good English and they were all quite friendly. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" ids="4117,4118,4119,4120,4121,4122" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""] As far as dining options on the island we BBQ'd several dinners at our campsite but we did have lunch at Isozakain (ãããããã) which was absolutely amazing and quite cheap at Â¥1600 per person (they do have several options - the most expensive is Â¥5500 per person). Also the YakinukuÂ Restaurant (åæè) served delicious ramen and gyoza as well as an extensive menu of Chinese food (they are located across the street from the big police station on 216). There are so many restaurants on the island that you'd probably need to stay for a week plus to try them all. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="4123,4125,4124"]
Of course I would be remiss to not mention the music festival, one of the main reasons why we came. The first night there was a torrential downpour (that flooded our tent) and so we opted not to ride our bikes the 2km in the dark to the festival. The second night the weather was great. The half moon was radiating on the ocean and the sky was filled with stars whileÂ silver cotton ball clouds drifted through the black night sky. [caption id="attachment_4126" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] The venue as seen from the "highway"[/caption] [playlist tracklist="false" artists="false" images="false" ids="4128"] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Dance party![/caption] We stayed out pretty late but not too late because we had an early morning the next day. We were headed to the even smaller island called Aogoshima!

item.title: Tosaku - Handmade Bamboo Fishing Rods
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
Before the age of graphite, carbon fiber, and fiber glass fishing rods were typically made out of bamboo. In Japan the bamboo fishing rodÂ is called wazao and is considered an art form, with craftsman spending a lifetime perfecting their art. Unfortunately, this exquisite art form is becoming more and more rare in Japan. This is due in part to decrease in demand, a decline in the availability of the necessary materials, and the fact that the trade does not provide enough income to compete with modern wages. In an effort to keep the tradition alive TosakuÂ ä¸ä½, which has been creatingÂ hand made fishing rods from bamboo for eight generations, has modernized their business model. Their main office is located a brisk 10 minute walk from Ueno Station in Tokyo and I highly recommend, that if you are in the area, you drop by. I came across Tosaku's website (they are the only wazao manufacturer with a modern website, part of their effort to stay afloat) after reading anÂ article in Craftsmanship. After reading the article I knew I needed to stop in and take a look at their lineup. Well that opportunity came when I found myself in Ueno visiting the Sansui Fishing Store to buy some fly tying equipment. Since the Tasaku office is so close I obviously hadÂ to stop in. The store has two isles, which are barely wide enough to fit down. All the shelves are loaded with bamboo rods and all other sorts of wooden fishing goods (e.g. tamos, bait boxes, wooden reels, etc...) The owner, Kouhei Matsumoto, andÂ his wife were inventorying goods inÂ the back but when I introduced myself they were very excited to show me around. I told them I was interested in Tenkara and he quickly ran to the front of the shop, grabbed a rod, and directed me outside. Once outsideÂ Matsumoto-sanÂ showed me an absolutely gorgeousÂ threeÂ piece bamboo Tenkara rod. The action was indescribably beautiful, I want one... No I need one. I swore I would never pay more than $300 for a rod but for this rod I will make an exception. It was a very hot day in Tokyo so after a brief demo we returned toÂ the cool air conditioned shop and chatted about fish. They presented me with a gift, a Tosaku scarf and after a few quick photos we exchanged business cards, and I returned to the streets of Tokyo - a smile on my face thoughts running through my headÂ about the fish I would catch on their bamboo rod when I returned to buy my own.

item.title: Aogashima
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
Before I moved to Japan my wife's Grandma emailed meÂ an article about a tiny island, way out in the ocean off the coast of Japan. She sent it to me with a quick note "You should visit this island sometime - Love, Grandma". After reading up on the island and how remote it is and difficult to access I was sold on visiting. Well it just so happens that the only way to get to the island is by ferry or helicopter, both of which depart from Hachijojima. Since we were already going to be there for the music festival we made plans to tack on a visit to this island, which is known as Aogashima, to our trip. Unfortunately, the helicopter service to the island has limited seats available and you can only book flights starting at noon 30 days prior to your trip. I logged on at 3pm and they were already sold out! So we were stuck with the ferry. The helicopter ride costs Â¥18,000+ per person round trip and the ferry costs Â¥5,500 per person round trip. While the ferry is obviously much cheaper,Â it is also very unreliable. The island has no natural harbor so if the seas are too rough the ferry is cancelled for the day. You can call (+81-4996-9-0033) the ferry at 0700 the day of your intended trip to find out if they are operating. If they are, there is one ferry that departs at 0930 and arrives at the island around three hours later. [caption id="attachment_4156" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Departing Hachijojima[/caption] We called the ferry at 0700 and luckily for us they were running. It was a madÂ scramble to tear down our campsite onÂ Hachijojima and return our rental car and bikes. It was a hectic morning but we boardedÂ the ferry with five minutes to spare. Once we left the island the skies cleared and the sun came out. The seas were still pretty rough but thankfully the Aogashima Maru (our ferry) was quite stable and we never got seasick. When Aogashima came into view, some three hours later, we were absolutely blown away by how blue the water was, how green the island was, and how rugged and austere it all looked. [caption id="attachment_4159" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] There is no natural port and the seas are so rough that they've built a crane to pluck the fishing boats from the ocean and put them on a platform on the side of a cliff![/caption] UponÂ landing safely on AogashimaÂ we were met by a city employee who told us that we needed to register at the city office by 5pm. We were also told that there were two rental car companies on the island but only one rented to campers. A city employee, who also apparently owned the rental car company, gave us a ride to the rental shop, where weÂ transferred our luggage into our rental kei van, and then we followed the city employeeÂ to the city office to register. At the city office we also picked out our campsite (we chose #8 & #9). After registering we made our wayÂ to the grocery store but on the way our car broke down and would not start again. So we called the lady up and she quickly returned and gave us a ride back to the rental car shop where we got another car (the cost is Â¥5,500 per day including gas and insurance). [caption id="attachment_4161" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] The rental car place (the electric Kei van is the owners)[/caption] After dealing with the car debacle we returned to the grocery store and bought dinner (there are no restaurants on the island. However, there are two Izakayas - one of which is only open on Wednesday). Then we drove to our campsite and set up camp. The campground is inside the crater on the side of the smaller volcano. The smaller volcano has many vents spewing steam out of the ground. We were told that sometimes the ground in the campsite can get very hot. I was skeptical about this, thinking maybe it was a lost in translation moment but it is veryÂ true - as I found out in the middle of the night. A short three minute walk from camp is the island's only onsen/sauna. The water and the sauna are heated by the volcanic steam and the ground all around the onsen is very hot. After setting up camp we drove back down to the port and did some snorkeling and spear fishing. My friend got a fish (!) but our swim was cut short when he was stung by a jellyfish (possibly a Portuguese Man-O-War). We piled back in the car and drove to the grocery store to get him some vinegar and then we headed to the onsen for a nice long soak. Between those two natural remedies the swelling went down quickly and within a few hours he was feeling much better. According to one of the locals August and September is the jellyfish migration, so if you are visiting at that time be careful. Next to the onsen/sauna the locals have built a stove that harnesses the volcanic steam to bake your foods. We cooked eggs, potatoes, and our fish in the "oven" and they tasted delicious! We also grilled some yakatori and sausage too back at camp. We ate like kings that night. [gallery size="full" type="default" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="4164,4166,4165"] The next day we explored the islands many sites and spectacular vistas of which my photos hardly do justice. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="4170,4171,4172"] The island has a small network of roads, many of which have fallen into the ocean a long time ago. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="4174,4175,4176"] We felt so blessed to visit the island during such great weather. During the day it was windy (which helped us deal with the humidity) and the sun was shining. At night you could see a million stars. Aogoshima is known for three things - its salt, the shochu, and star gazing. All of which we sampled and thoroughly enjoyed.. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="4178,4179,4181"] On the day we were supposed to head back to Hachijojima to catch our flight home there was a 20-30% chance that the seas would be too rough for the ferry to land. With the fast approaching swells from yet another typhoon we would possibly be stuck on the islandÂ for another week! Thank God the ferry was able to land and we were able to get off the island. Not that we didn't thoroughly enjoy our time on the islandÂ we just were not adequately prepared to weather a typhoon, in our three season tent, on a tiny island in the middle of the Pacific Ocean. [caption id="attachment_4180" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Sunset on the flight back to TokyoÂ from Hachijojima[/caption]

item.title: Nikko National Park
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
The city of Nikko, located in Tochigi Prefecture, is quite popular with tourists. I had visited a few months ago and had a great time visiting the Nikko Tosho-gu and Futarasanjinja - but the natural beauty of Nikko was the real draw for me. The Yutaki waterfall, Ryuzu waterfall, SenjogaharaÂ wetlands, LakeÂ Chuzenji, and Yuno Lake were absolutely beautiful and considerably less crowded (the way I like it) then Nikko city proper. Still one trip wasn't enough and I resolved to visit the region again for some more in-depth exploration. Well that opportunity arose when John Vetterli from Tenkara Guides LLC emailed me about GregÂ from Colorado who was traveling to Japan and wanted to squeeze in a day of Tenkara between business meetings. Fortunately,Â I was able to fitÂ him into my schedule the day before I needed to be in Tadami in the Aizu Region of Fukushima Prefecture. So we planned to meet in Nikko National Park for a day of exploring and Tenkara since it was on the way to Tadami. I drove up to Nikko National Park the day before both to do some scouting and to beat the Silver Week crowded highways. I arrived in the late afternoon and was able to getÂ in a bit of fishing. One thing I quickly discovered was that the pressure was high on the streams within Nikko National Park. Still there were a decent amount of fish in the rivers, you just had to bringÂ your A game to catch them. The streams also tended to be low gradient, which meant that there were long stretches of flat water that typically don't hold fish (at least this late in the season). That night I camped out in my Kei van at the YunishigawaÂ Michi-No-EkiÂ deep in the Nikko National Park. The place was nearly deserted, there was only one other group staying that night - a very sweet couple from Switzerland Anook and Freddie. We talked about Japan and our various adventures for quite awhile before we both crawled into our kitted out camper vans for the night. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" ids="4208,4206,4207" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""] The next morning I did a bit more scouting, then headed down toÂ Kawajiyumoto Station to pick up Greg. The drive to the river fromÂ Kawajiyumoto station only took about 20 minutes and under a hazy blue sky we plunged into the frigid keiryu and began working our way upstream. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" ids="4216,4217,4218,4219,4220,4221,4222" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""] The river was mainly inhabited by Iwana, and we did see some big ones, but Iwana can be a very elusive. They have about 7Â° blind spot out of each eye, which is directly behind them. They are also very sensitive to shadows, colors, and movement. With a 350Â° range of view, you have to sneak up directly behind them. In small keiryu and genryu this is easier but in mid-sized to big rivers it can prove difficult. Wearing natural colors, staying low, and moving very stealthily when approaching a possible fish holding spot are all good techniques. Also being able to cast accurately with long lines and not laying a lot of line in the water is crucial. Still, even when you employ all these techniques flawlessly you still need a healthy dose of luck. Throughout the day we spotted close to two dozen fish but only brought one to hand. But fishing isn't just about the fish, it is also about the places you go and the people you go with. The river valley was gorgeous and we saw no signs of recent passage. The water, which flows fromÂ Miyoriyama, was cold, clear, and deep - despite a dryer than normal summer. Throughout Nikko National Park the lakes were very low and some streams had been reduced to a trickle as Greg and I found out when we decided to try our luck in a few other rivers. The time came to quickly for Greg to leave. I dropped him off at the train station and after a quick stop to soak my feet in a foot onsen I hit the road my destination - the Aizu Region of Fukushima Prefecture. [caption id="attachment_4225" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Photo Credit - Greg took a lot of the photos I used for this article, thank you for letting me use them Greg. I'll definitely look you up next time in the Boulder area![/caption]

item.title: Exploring Aizu - The Majestic Interior of Fukushima Prefecture
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
After spending a few days in Nikko National Park, I was ready to leave the Silver Week crowds behind and find some solitude. So I hit the road. My destination? Tadami, a small city in western Fukushima Prefecture. I had been invited by Adam Trahan to join him and Adam Klags along with a large group of Japanese Tenkara anglers for two days in theÂ 250+ year old Kanozu Guard House (å¶æ´¥çªæ) . I had never met any of them before and I was excited to put some faces to names and to hopefully make some newÂ friends too. The drive from Nikko National Park into Aizu, which is the westernmost region of Fukushima Prefecture, was pleasant with a lot of rivers to distract me from my goal of making it to the Kirara 289 Michi-No-EkiÂ by nightfall. When I finally pulled into the Michi-No-Eki I found the parking lot nearly filled with campers, vans, and motorcycles. Thankfully I got a spot and after a short walk to the Hello Shop convenience store for some supplies I settled in for the night making ramen on my camp stove and enjoying the sound of the river flowing next to my van. That night as I slept the skies opened up and it rained hard the whole night. [caption id="attachment_4231" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Somewhere in Aizu[/caption] The next morning my excitement awoke me early. There was a valley below Mt. Taishaku (å¸éå±±) from which emanated a promising looking river system. I had found this area on a cartoon map hanging on the wall in the Michi-No-Eki the night before. I was itchingÂ for an adventure and this had the makings of oneÂ written all over it. After about an hour of driving I turned off the main "highway" onto a side road that quickly turned to dirt. As I continued deeper into the valley I came across car after car parked on the side of the road. They were all anglers. I was dismayed, this much pressure surely meant that the fishing would be challenging. But I had driven this far I was not going to be deterred. I found an empty turn out, donned my sawanobori and rain gear, and plunged into woods towards the cacophony of the river. When I arrived I noticed that the water was a tannin brown tint. The rain from last night had obviously caused some flooding. A little discouraged I deployed my rod and began fishing the spots where I thought the fish might be holding while they waited for the flood waters to subside. After a few minutes I caught sight of two Tenkara anglers up river from me, so I put my rod away and ducked into the woods aiming for a nearby tributary in hopes of finding some fish and solitude. [caption id="attachment_4232" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] The rain really picked up when I arrived so I didn't get too many photos... This is a photo of the river on the way out. Definitely some big water.[/caption] The tributary looked very promising and it was running very very cold and clear. I fished a goodÂ length of it but didn't see a single fish or get one bite. I turned around when my rain jacket soaked through and I began to shiver in the 15Â°C temps. Back at the van and not quite ready to give up, I doubled back to a stream I had passed on the way in and fished the lower section. I was hopeful that this section would have been skipped by those heading deeper into the mountains. My intuitionÂ proved fruitful and I got threeÂ strong bites, saw several fish, and even managed to bring one to hand too! [caption id="attachment_4235" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] I'm pretty sure the native Iwana are the ones with big tails. The stocked fish don't need such powerful appendages in the ponds where they grow up. I released this guy.[/caption] By now my clothes were completely soaked and my body, which was accustomed to the summer heat, was turning blue from the cold rain and the frigid keiryu... So I returned to my van, donned some dry clothes, and gorged myself on snacks before making my way back to civilization. Back on the road I made good time to Tadami and arrived several hours before everyone was scheduled to arrive. With some time to kill I decided to visit a river I'd dreamed of fishing for awhile. The road into the area was epic (and I've driven a lot of roads in Japan - this one was extra spicy). Once I found a spot to park, figuring out how to get to the river proved to be veryÂ complicated. I finally resorted in falling down a cliff to get to the bottom (thank God there was a random tree that broke my fall, or else it would have been bad). Like the river early that day this river also had a tannin brown tinge which madeÂ finding fish interested in eating a lot of work. I found one. Still I had dreamed of fishing this river ever since I'd seen it on video, and the fact alone that I was there made itÂ super special. Even ifÂ I only got one bite and scared the living sh*# out of myself, it was besides the point. If the fall intoÂ the canyon was scary the climb out was on a whole other level - surrounded by roaring waterfalls and rotten vines the ascent back to the "road" was harrowing. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="slider" ids="4240,4241,4242" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""] After three days of living in my van and fishing, I was starting to smell like a Tanuki. So before I made my to theÂ bansho (akaÂ Kanozu Guard House (å¶æ´¥çªæ)) I stopped by a river next to a large rice field and took a bath with some soap. When I arrived at the bansho there were two tour busses parked out front but I braved the crowds and soon enough I spotted Sebata-san sitting at a table surrounded by a group of laughing Japanese men. I introduced myself and listened in to the conversation which had something to do with level line, kebari presentation, and Sebata-san's furled line (and it's obvious merits above level line). It was a conversation that made me really wish that my Japanese was better. Soon enough Adam-san (Trahan) and Adam-chan (Klags) showed up withÂ Go Ishii,Â Keiji Ito, &Â Keiichi Okushi. There were so many great folks in attendance that night - all under the roof of a building almost as old as the United States and at a table over flowing with a smorgasbord of delicious Japanese foods. It didn't seem real. Adam Trahan put together a very good report of the whole evening (plus the adventure before too that you shouldn't miss). I won't try and compete - rather I'll just share a few of my photos, encourage you to come to the Land of the Rising Sun yourself, and leave a link to Adam's post here. [gallery link="file" type="carousel" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" columns="2" size="full" ids="4247,4248,4249,4250,4251,4252,4253"] The next morning the rain was still coming down and I abandoned any hope of squeezing in a quick Tenkara session before heading home.Â Instead I got a much better offer - visitÂ Yamano-san's "Luxury Kazusao Yamano fishing tackle shop" (é«ç´åç«¿ å±±éé£å·åº) in Saitama, Tokyo. He wanted to teach me how to make a bamboo rod, I emphatically agreed. After packing up I beganÂ saying good bye to everyone, I showed Sebata-san my sugegasa and told him that I was emulating him. He laughed and ducked into a back room with my sugegasa. He returned a short while later having loaded my fly patch, on the inside brim, with several of his hand tied kebari!! I haven't decided yet if I will fish with them or save them for posterity. A gift like that is something very special. [caption id="attachment_4255" align="aligncenter" width="960"] Photo Credit Â© Maruyama-san Headwaters Magazine[/caption] The good byes were strangely difficult as I had only known the group for less than 24 hours. But I felt a strong kindred spirit between all of us. Despite varying backgrounds, language, religions, politics, and beliefs we were bonded together by the same passion. A passion that could be defined as Tenkara but it goes so much deeper than just that one word. For me this trip had been about immersing myselfÂ in a glorious natural world, enjoying the gifts given to me, expressing them through my meagerÂ talents, and then sharing them with a group of like minded individuals all struggling to put into words the majesty of the past few days spent in the keiryu of Japan.

item.title: Genryu Tenkara
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
âGenryuâ is the most upper part of a river, even upper part of âkeiryu(mountain stream)â and here in Japan [the] image of âGenryuâ is always with fast flow of gin clear water running through big rocks in a beautiful valley surrounded by flourishing forests of the mountains.
Tenkara Fisher March 2014Â "'Genryu Fishing' of Japan" byÂ Keiichi Okushi
You can find Genryu (it is pronounced g-en [as in Ken but with a 'G' or Again without the 'A'] roo) pretty muchÂ anywhere there is a mountain in Japan (Japan is 80% mountains so there are a lot of genryu). UnfortunatelyÂ they are some of the moreÂ threatened waterways in the 'Land of the Rising Sun'. A lotÂ of the genryuÂ tend to be overfished and consequently there just aren't very many, if any fish left. A general rule of thumb in Japan is that if the fish is longer than 15cm (a length typically achieved in one season of growth) you can take it home. A good sign you are fishing a heavily pressured genryuÂ is if all the fish are tiny. This is because none of the fish live through a season. The biggest threat by far thoughÂ is the Japanese affinity for dams. There are over 100,000 dams in Japan and it has really hurt the fish populations, especially in the genryu. So while there are genryu all over Japan finding ones that have not been decimated by the lack of a catch and release culture and dams can be challenging. I had a great conversation with Go-Ishii about this during my visit to Aizu. One thing he told me that I found very encouraging was that foreigners (those who are not Japanese citizens of Japanese ancestry) have a real opportunity to fast track a revolution inÂ how the Japanese view fish, angling, and proper land stewardship. It seems hardly a week goes by that I do not get an email, read an article, or watch a video about how dams are being torn down, river habitat restored, and native fish are being reintroduced into areas throughout the United States of America (and Britain too). While there is a lot of work left to do and a lot of battles to still be fought, it is encouraging to see a nation waking up to the realities of how several centuries of un-checked greed has damaged theirÂ precious resources. If this attitude of protecting theÂ land and its natural inhabitants is just getting on its feet in the "west"Â it has barely been conceived in Japan. In my article "Conversing In Japanese" which was featured in the Fall 2016 issue of Tenkara Angler, I said that I "believe[d] that every Tenkara angler should make a pilgrimage to Japan not just for the fishing but to immerse themselves in another culture. Too many of the problems currently facing the âwestâ today, could be easily resolved with a little perspective, grace, and respect. Something that Japan, its people, and its culture can offer in spades."Â While there is definitely something we can learn from visiting (or even better living for awhile in) Japan there is also something we as anglers can teach them. Namely the merits of catch and release (along with proper handling of fish during the release process) and how to be good stewards of the land through habitat restoration and realizing the consequences of the unchecked construction of dams, bridges, tunnels, and roads. Now just so you know, there are a lot of genryu with plenty of fish near heavily populated areas like the Kanto Plain (where Tokyo resides), you just have to be up for an adventure to get there. If the access is easy, then the area will most likely see a lot of angling pressure (isn't this true though on every continent?). So strap on a pair of sawanobori shoes, throw a rope in your pack, and be prepared for some excitement. Case inÂ point - my latest (and the last proper genryu) trip for the 2016 Tenkara season was an absolute blast and the genryu was LOADED with Iwana.

ToÂ continue reading about my latest adventure in the Genryu of Japan click page 2

My alarm's screeching startled me from a pleasant dream. To fully cement my wakefulness my wife groaned and gave me a sleepyÂ shove, she still had a few hours to sleep before it was time for her to get up and go to work. I stumbled out of bed, flipped on the coffee maker, and climbed into the shower (there is no better way to wake up before the sun than a shower). Soon enough I found myself behind the wheel of my friends Subaru XV on a Japanese toll-road, the sun cresting over the horizon forcing me to don my sunglasses. It was a beautiful morning and the days prospects were prominent in my mind as we discussed all manner of subjects between our second languages. Soon enough we were struggling beneath our 50lb packs up an old dirt road deep in the mountains of Oze National Park. About half wayÂ into our hike we stopped to rehydrate and replenish our energy reserves on Asahi beer and chiruoshi (ãããªã) aka hardyÂ kiwis. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="4274,4280,4276,4275,4279"] After our break, the ominous clouds finally delivered the contents that we hoped they would spare us. It rained heavily for the next several hours. The rain was just a continuation of an exceptionally wet month. All hopes of having a campfire that night were extinguished by each plump rain drop that fell from the grey sky... but that did not stop us from trying anyways. [caption id="attachment_4278" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Go camping in a rain storm. It will make you more appreciate the comforts you have in this modern day and age.[/caption] Our campsite was one of dreams. We were on the edge of a meadow a babbling brook cascading down a hillside covered in bamboo and a river not more than 10' away with a thousand happy Iwana swimming in its depths [gallery link="file" type="slider" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" columns="2" size="full" ids="4287,4288,4284,4289"] The rain and the snow come down from heaven, and do not return to it without watering the earth and making it bud and flourish, so that it yields seed for the sower, bread for the eater, 'and fish for the angler'. Over the next three days I brought to hand over 30 Iwana with another 20 or so that gave chase to my fly or got off before I could properly "catch" them. It was by far one of the best (if not the best days) of fishing I've had in Japan. There wasn't a dam in site (except at the end of the third day when we were fishing closer to 'civilization') and we did not see any people until the hike out (and they were biologist maintaining/monitoring deer migration routes). [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" ids="4290,4291,4292,4293,4294,4295,4296" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""] The second night the rain subsided and a million stars glistened through the leaves that were dancing in the intermittent breeze. As the night drew on, the temperatures dropped to nearly freezing!Â As I shivered in my 0Â° C rated bag I reminded myself to remember the day when I wasÂ cold and needed a beanie and a jacket. After a long warm summer the first cold days are a God send. The third day we packed up camp and headed back to the car but not before making a short detour to fish a promising tributary that yielded another dozen fish and a handful or two of yamabudo (å±±ã¶ã©ã) aka mountain grapes. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="4298,4299,4300,4297,4305"] The genryu of Japan are absolutely beautiful and totally unique, anyone that has fished one knows it. They offer a fishing experience that is hard, if not impossible, to replicate anywhere else in the world. If you haven't already you would be remiss not to make plans right now to visit next season - early April through late June are the best months. If you come early enough you can catch the cherry blossoms and make sure you have some soba, sashimi, and ramen too. This country is something you should experience at least once in your life.

item.title: Goby Fishing
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
Last month I travelled to the Aizu Region of Fukushima PrefectureÂ and met up with some of the preeminent Japanese and American Tenkara ambassadors for a social gathering, in a building older than the United States. During this eventÂ I was invited by Masayuki Yamano-san to go ãã¼ fishing with him the following month. Yamano-san owns a speciality rod shop in Saitama, Tokyo where he practices the ancient Japanese art form of Kazusao (åç«¿) or hand making bamboo fishing rods. I immediately accepted his invitation despite knowing next to nothing aboutÂ ãã¼ or the fishing style. [caption id="attachment_4330" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] The crew hard at Goby fishing![/caption] In Japan Goby fish are called HazeÂ ãã¼ (pronounced ha-zay) and despite their small size they are a very popular game fish. Most Goby akaÂ ãã¼ are 5-10cm long but they they can grow much bigger during the spawning season - it just isn't very common. GobiesÂ ãã¼ habitat is found in shallow brackish water with sandy and muddy sea bottoms, which is pretty common around Tokyo. GobyÂ ãã¼ season starts around June but they are more difficult to catch then due to their very small size. Starting mid-July through October the fish stature increases and they become much easier to catch using bait. In fact they are so easy to catch that the record for the most caught in a single day isÂ 1,500! [caption id="attachment_4348" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] About five minutes into the morning! Goby really are easy to catch.[/caption]

Fast forward to the pre-determined date in October and I awoke before the sun to catch the first train out of Yokosuka. My destination was Myoden Station in Edogawa Tokyo. Some two hours later I arrived and jumpedÂ in my friend Go Ishii-san's car for the quick drive to the Edogawa River and the docks where our charterÂ Itoyusen, operates from. We met the crew at the pier and after stocking up on some last minute beer from the vending machine we boarded our boat. A few minutes later the boat captainÂ anchored us in the river and we began rigging our lines. The water was only about 1.5-2 meters deep. Since Goby prefer to feed on the bottom you fish with a fixed line about 60cm longer than the water depth and a heavy weight attached near the hook. For bait we used worms and scallops.

[gallery link="file" type="carousel" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" columns="2" size="full" ids="4336,4337,4338,4339,4340,4341,4335"] Goby are very easy to catch. I probably caught somewhere around 20 fish and I was more focussed on talking and hanging out than fishing. For every 50 bites or so I would succeed in catching a Gobi, theyÂ are quite adept at cleaning onesÂ hook without getting caught. About halfway through the day Yamano-san let me borrow one of his bambooÂ ãã¼ rods. I was very impressed at not only the exquisite craftsmanship but how sensitive yet firm the rod was. I could feel every little bite so much more clearly than with my Tenkara rod. The rod felt very supple and soft yet when I set the hook it felt like a stiffer rod. It is kind of hard to explain, it is something that must be felt to be believed. I cannot wait to start making my own bamboo rod next month! [caption id="attachment_4350" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Getting a lesson from Go Ishii-san and Oreo-san on how to use Yamano-san's bamboo ãã¼ rod[/caption] After five hours of fishing we summoned the boat captain from shore and returned to the pier. On the way back Ishii-san and I dumped our bucket with about 75 fish in it back into the river. We already had plenty of fish for everyone and Goby aren't the easiest to clean (they're small and slippery factor in a bit too much to drink and a moving boat and it was a miracle no one lost a finger) There was a nice park next to the river and in no time flat we had a full on BBQ going with pig intestines, some sort of sausage made from the fat of a cows placenta, and Goby tempura (oh and a few liters of beer too). It was all delicious, I am very much hooked on Japanese stream side BBQ now :) [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] It's a good thing no one had a permanent maker :)[/caption] [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" ids="4344,4345,4346,4347" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""] After eating all the BBQ we packed up and headed down to a local restaurant where we continued the party for another couple of hours. It was a great way to wrap up a wonderful day hanging out with friends, making new ones, and trying soba water sochi (which is quite delicious). Unfortunately with a two hour train ride to get home I had to say goodbye too soon, but I am looking forward to my next fishing outing with Yamano-san and his illustrious crew!

In Japan ãã¼ Haze fish (aka Goby fish) are a very popular game fish because they are plentiful, easy to catch, and taste quite good as tempura.

item.title: Ayu
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
Ayu are a highly sought after game fish in Japan, some of the best rivers in Japan that they call home are highly revered. 30-40 years ago, before Japan began making dams at a breakneck speed - Ayu would swim up the rivers from the ocean, much like salmon or steelhead. Now a days Ayu are mostly stocked but you can still find them in rivers close to the ocean, below the impassable barriers that have sprung up in the rivers they have called home for centuries. Izu Peninsula is one of these places (especially on the Suruga Bay side) where Ayu can still swim pretty far upstream from the ocean. These rivers are also inhabited by sea run Amago, which are quite fun to catch with a Tenkara rod. Last year I traveled to this paradise of striking sea cliffs, white sandy beaches, trout streams, and warm water and caught my first two Amago! This year Kado-san and I returned for three days and two nights to see if we could find a few more Amago. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Not my photo courtesy of Â©Wikipedia-Japan[/caption] The morning of day one started early but within a few hours we were parked near the first river which was nestled in a beautiful valley surrounded by citrus trees. It was nearly time for the harvest and the air was filled with the scent of tangerines, oranges, and lemons. After a few hours of fishing, we came across two Amago fighting (or maybe rough spawning...?) in a nice pool. We watched them splash in the water for awhile and then turned around and headed back to the vanÂ and drove to our usual camping spot. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="4380,4381,4382,4383,4384,4385,4386,4396"] We setup camp and after soaking in the hot sun for awhile I went for a swim in the crystal clear bay next to our free campsite. When I got back to camp a local was talking to Kado-san, his name was Ma-chan (short for Matsumoto). After chatting for a while he disappeared only to return shortly with a few cold beers and some sashimi. A few hours later we followed Ma-chanÂ to a "secret" locals only pool in the keiryu that flowed through the village. Ma-chan handed me a spear and goggles and pointed me towards the water. Within a few minutes I had speared two Ayu! Besides being freezing from swimming in the cold keiryu I was pretty excited to have gotten two fish my first time using a spear. We cooked up the AyuÂ at Ma-chan's house and then stopped in at the locals only onsen for a nice soak. The next day we fished two rivers, including the one right next to our beachside campsite. Unfortunately we didn't catch any fish nor see any Amago (I did see a TON of Ayu though). It was such a beautiful day and I was so happy to be fishing with my Tenkara rod again that it didn't matter. [caption id="attachment_4398" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Signs of Ayu feeding on algae were prevalent[/caption] While we were fishing thoughÂ Kado-san came across two fresh water crabs that we brought back to camp with us. So we weren't completely skunked. We steamed the crabsÂ in some wine while the camp fire crackled in the evening's dark sky dotted with glistening stars. It was a magical evening. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="4393,4392,4391,4397,4389,4390,4394,4388,4375"] The next day we packed up camp, said goodbye to Ma-chan, and headed south for lunch at a famous Unagi restaurant. After lunch we stopped by a free outdoor onsen. Unfortunately, the water was WAY to hot for me to even bear for a second so we hit the road and began making our way home, but not before we stopped to visit of a few of Kado-san's friend who owned a potato farm near Ito. [gallery link="file" type="carousel" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" columns="2" size="full" ids="4405,4403,4402,4400,4404,4399,4401"] After a quick visit we got back on the road, we had one more stop to make. Kado-san hadÂ a friend who is a bamboo rod maker. He lived in Atami, which was on the way home for us, and he wanted to introduce me and show me his workshop... Stay tuned for a full report from my visit with the Edo Wazao master. [caption id="attachment_4407" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Left to Right: Kado-san, Ma-chan, Me (Isaac)[/caption]

item.title: Herabuna Bamboo Rods
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded: Herabuna are a sub-species of Carp that are a very popular game fish in Japan. The style of fishing for Herabuna is the antithesis of Tenkara. While both utilize a fixed line fishing method with rods that breakdown or collapse that is about where theÂ similarities end. Herabuna fishing utilizes bait, is primarily catch and release (due to the taste of the fish), and requires hours of patiently sitting (literally) in one spot. Herabuna rods come in all lengths and cover the full gambit of the flex scale. The stiffer Herabuna rods are similar toÂ a softish Tenkara rod. Some Japanese websites that I have visited even suggest that Herabuna rods can be used to catch all manner of fish with both bait and flies. This is an interesting hypothesis that I would like to explore more of. I am a now a huge fan of bamboo rods - and not just for their aesthetics but their ability to translate even the smallest bites into very perceptible tremors at the handle. A fact that I came to discover during my recent haze fishing trip where we were catching fish no bigger than 7.5cm. A few months ago I met with Adam-san and Adam-chan as well as a large group of Tenkara anglers in the Aizu region of Fukushima Prefecture (if you haven't read my trip report please check it out here). During that trip I got to knowÂ a lot of big names in the Japanese Tenkara community, one of which is Yamano-san. Yamano-san makes beautiful bamboo fishing rods. While I was inÂ Aizu Yamano-san offered to teach me the art of Edo-Wazao and so next month I will startÂ studying under his tutelage the art of makingÂ bamboo fishing rods! Needless to sayÂ I was very excited when my friend Kado-san offered to introduce me to Hajime Murai (ç«¿å§«) a Herabuna bamboo rod maker living in Atami. Atami is located on the Sagami Bay side of Izu Peninsula very close to where we had spent three days camping and Tenkara fishing on the peninsula. So it was very convenientÂ to stop in and visitÂ Murai-san's shop/residence on the way home. Not to mention I was eager to learn more about Edo-Wazao. [caption id="attachment_4424" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Hajime Murai (ç«¿å§«) in his wood shop[/caption] We spent several hours chatting discussing all manner of subjects.Â Hajime Murai (ç«¿å§«) has an impressive collection of hand tied flies as well as hand carved lures. In fact he was heavily promoting fishing with one of his wooden lures and a fly attached together. Murai-san is an avid western fly fisherman (aka with a reel) and likes to use both a lure and a fly when he fishes. It is a technique he swears by. [caption id="attachment_4425" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Hajime Murai (ç«¿å§«) hand carves some very exquisiteÂ Tamo fishing nets![/caption] [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height="" ids="4426,4427,4428,4429,4430,4431"] While we were chatting Murai-san and Kado-san were pulling hundreds of bamboo fishing rods out of storage and going through them one by one. When I asked Kado-san what they were looking for he told me that Murai-san wanted to give me a rod that was stiff enough to be used as a Tenkara rod! I was very honored and a little taken aback by such a generous gift (not to mention he had already given me a bamboo Tamo. It wasn't finished though so he told me to come back in the spring and he would have it finished for me). I ended up leaving that evening with two Herabuna bamboo fishing rods that Murai-san had made in 1980!!

Herabuna are a species of Carp. They are a highly praised sport fish in Japan and are so popular that special rods have been made to target them.

item.title: November
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
November is a beautiful month in Japan - the fall colors are in full swing, the days are cool the evenings are brisk, and preparations are in full swing for snow. However, the lull between Tenkara season and ski season requires that I get creative to find things to do. Luckily, there is a seemingly endless plethora of outdoor activities to enjoy in Japan.

Wakasagi Fishing on Lake Sagamiko

Wakasagi also known as Smelt is a very popular game fish in Japan. Even though these fish are only a few inches long Wakasagi anglers really get into it with some impressive gear. [caption id="attachment_4462" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Lake Sagmiko[/caption] [caption id="attachment_4471" align="aligncenter" width="768"] This is way more comfortable than Tenkara[/caption] [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" ids="4470,4463,4464,4465,4466,4467,4468,4469" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""]

Mountain Biking

Izu PeninsulaÂ  This area offers some pretty spectacular views of Mt. Fuji,Â Uchiura Bay, and Suruga Bay. [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" ids="4478,4479,4480,4481,4482,4483" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""]
Chiba Prefecture [caption id="attachment_4491" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Toyofusa Lake[/caption] There is some fun trails in the Chiba Forest and around Mt. Kano - but I'm not going to tell you exactly where they are... You'll just have to find them yourself ;) [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="carousel" ids="4486,4487,4488,4489,4490" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""] The Fall colors are amazing this year and Toyohide Waterfall was raging from all the rain.
I have also been busy with some guest writing on Discover Tenkara and Tenkara Talk - it has been a busy month. I also squeezed in a trip to UratanzawaÂ where the Rainbow are getting huge! I brought one to hand but the camera was in the car. The rest broke the 5x tippet like it was thread. [gallery columns="2" size="full" ids="4493,4494" link="file" type="default" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""] Seriously I can't get over the Fall colors this year! They're epic.

November is a beautiful month in Japan - the fall colors are in full swing, the days are cool and the evenings nippy, and snow is just around the corner!

item.title: Japanese Craftsmanship
item.dc:creator: isaacmtait
item.content:encoded:
The craftsmanship of Japanese artisans is extraordinary - a fact known to many but one that has become more apparentÂ to me through first hand experience. Last month, Discover Tenkara featured my article about Yamano-san, and hisÂ bamboo fishing rod craftsmanship. Then a few weeks later Jason Klass at Tenkara Talk featured my articleÂ "Kado-san's Christmas Kebari" about Kado-san's shokuryosha like kebari. So in the same vein ofÂ Japanese craftsmanship,Â I am sharing some more exquisite Japanese craftsmanship that I've discovered recently.
Miya Shoji, Japanese carpenter transplanted to New York City to perfect his carpentry. It's a fascinating video and well worth watching imo.
Hitoshi Kondo-san
[caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Hitoshi Kondo-san is second from the left (holding the white plastic bag).[/caption] I met Kondo-san on aÂ Wakasagi fishing trip to Sagamiko last month. He struck me as very quiet and humble but at the end of the day we ended up taking the same train and I got to know him better. He lives north of Tokyo near Kamikawa, where he lives a simple life so that he can focus on his passion - Japanese bamboo basket making. He has dedicated his life to making some absolutely beautiful baskets. He claims that he is still learning but to me his baskets don't look like they can get any better!
Toshiaka Kado-san
[caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="768"] Kado-san displaying his artwork in front of his shop. He also made the stained glass panels behind him.[/caption] Kado-san has become a very good friend of mine but he is also a man of many secrets. I knew him for over a year before I found out he makes stained glass. His artwork is displayed throughout his storeÂ located not to far from my home. [caption id="attachment_4515" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] His glasswork shop also doubles as his fly tying station.[/caption] When my wife and I eventually return to the United States we are looking forward to incorporating his beautiful stained glass into the tiny home we hope to build for our growing family. Not only will the beauty inspire us everyday but it will remind us of the wonderful experiences we had when we lived in the Land of the Rising Sun... [gallery columns="2" size="full" type="imagecarousel" ids="4516,4517,4518,4519,4520" link="file" caption="default" masonry="default" width="" height=""]
Every time I hold a piece of Japanese craftsmanship, whether it be a hand carved wooden pen from a Post TownÂ or even a bamboo bait fishing basket, I am drawn to the attention to detail and pride the worker exhibits in their craft. TheÂ self-respect, patience, and skillÂ that they exhibit in their work is certainly a breath of fresh air. Some things never change or go out of style, and for that I am grateful.
